Lewis | title = Noninvasive Measurement of Carboxyhemoglobin: How Accurate is Accurate Enough? | journal = Annals of Emergency Medicine | volume = 56 | issue = 4 | pages = 389–91 | publisher = | location = Boston, MA | year = 2010 | doi=10.1016/j.annemergmed.2010.05.025}} The use of a regular [[pulse oximeter]] is not effective in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning as people with carbon monoxide poisoning may have a normal [[oxygen saturation]] level on a pulse oximeter.{{cite journal|vauthors=Vegfors M, Lennmarken C |title=Carboxyhaemoglobinaemia and pulse oximetry|journal=British Journal of Anaesthesia|volume=66|issue=5|pages=625–626|date=May 1991|pmid=2031826|doi=10.1093/bja/66.5.625}} This is due to the carboxyhemoglobin being misrepresented as oxyhemoglobin.{{cite journal|vauthors=Barker SJ, Tremper KK |title=The effect of carbon monoxide inhalation on pulse oximetry and transcutaneous PO2|journal=Anesthesiology|volume=66|issue=5|pages=677–79|date=May 1987|pmid=3578881|doi=10.1097/00000542-198705000-00014}} [[Carbon monoxide breath monitor|Breath CO monitoring]] offers an alternative to pulse CO-oximetry. Carboxyhemoglobin levels have been shown to have a strong correlation with breath CO concentration.{{cite journal|first=M.|last=Jarvis|year=1986|title=Low cost carbon monoxide monitors in smoking assessment|journal=Thorax|pages=886–87|doi=10.1136/thx.41.11.886|volume=41|issue=11|pmc=460516}}{{cite journal|first=Nicholas|last=Wald|year=1981|title=Carbon monoxide in breath in relation to smoking and carboxyhaemoglobin levels|journal=Thorax|pages=366–69|doi=10.1136/thx.36.5.366|pmid=7314006|pmc=471511|volume=36|issue=5}} However, many of these devices require the user to inhale deeply and hold their breath to allow the CO in the blood to escape into the lung before the measurement can be made. As this is not possible in people who are unresponsive, these devices may not appropriate for use in on-scene emergency care detection of CO poisoning. === Differential diagnosis === There are many conditions to be considered in the differential diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning.{{cite journal |vauthors=Kao LW, Nañagas KA |title=Toxicity associated with carbon monoxide |journal=Clinics in Laboratory Medicine |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=99–125 |date=March 2006 |pmid=16567227 |doi=10.1016/j.cll.2006.01.005}}{{cite web | last =Shochat | first =Guy N | title =Toxicity, Carbon Monoxide | publisher =[[emedicine]] | date =17 February 2009 | url =http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | accessdate =2009-04-27 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090309072832/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | archivedate =9 March 2009 | df = }} The earliest symptoms, especially from low level exposures, are often non-specific and readily confused with other illnesses, typically [[influenza|flu-like viral syndromes]], [[clinical depression|depression]], [[chronic fatigue syndrome]], [[chest pain]], and [[migraine]] or other headaches.{{cite journal | vauthors=Ilano AL, Raffin TA | title=Management of carbon monoxide poisoning | journal=Chest | date=Jan 1990 | pages=165–69 | volume=97 | issue=1 | pmid=2403894 | doi=10.1378/chest.97.1.165 }} Carbon monoxide has been called a "great mimicker" due to the presentation of poisoning being diverse and nonspecific. Other conditions included in the differential diagnosis include [[acute respiratory distress syndrome]], [[altitude sickness]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[diabetic ketoacidosis]], [[meningitis]], [[methemoglobinemia]], or [[Opioid overdose|opioid]] or toxic alcohol poisoning. == Prevention == [[File:CO DETECTOR (cropped).JPG|thumb|Carbon monoxide detector connected to a North American power outlet]] === Detectors === [[File:COMonitor.jpg|thumb|A carbon monoxide monitor clipped to the uniform of a paramedic]] Prevention remains a vital [[public health]] issue, requiring public education on the safe operation of appliances, heaters, fireplaces, and internal-combustion engines, as well as increased emphasis on the installation of [[carbon monoxide detector]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=339|issue=22|pages=1603–08|date=November 1998|pmid=9828249|doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=9828249&promo=ONFLNS19}} Carbon monoxide is tasteless and odourless, and therefore can not be detected by visual cues or smell.{{cite journal |title=Compressed breathing air – the potential for evil from within |vauthors=Millar IL, Mouldey PG |year=2008 |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=145–51 |journal=Diving and Hyperbaric Medicine |publisher=[[South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society]] |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |accessdate=2013-04-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225063245/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |archivedate=2010-12-25 |df= |pmid=22692708 }} The United States [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]] has stated, "carbon monoxide detectors are as important to home safety as smoke detectors are," and recommends each home have at least one carbon monoxide detector, and preferably one on each level of the building. These devices, which are relatively inexpensive and widely available, are either battery- or AC-powered, with or without battery backup.{{cite web|last=Lipinski|first=Edward R|title=Keeping Watch on Carbon Monoxide|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 14, 1999|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|accessdate=2009-09-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623100533/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|archivedate=June 23, 2011|df=}} In buildings, carbon monoxide detectors are usually installed around heaters and other equipment. If a relatively high level of carbon monoxide is detected, the device sounds an alarm, giving people the chance to evacuate and ventilate the building.{{cite journal |vauthors=Krenzelok EP, Roth R, Full R |title=Carbon monoxide ... the silent killer with an audible solution |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |date=September 1996 |pages=484–86 |volume=14 |issue=5 |pmid=8765117 |doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(96)90159-X }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Yoon SS, Macdonald SC, Parrish RG |title=Deaths from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning and potential for prevention with carbon monoxide detectors |journal=JAMA |date=March 1998 |pages=685–87 |volume=279 |issue=9 |pmid=9496987 |doi=10.1001/jama.279.9.685 }} Unlike [[smoke detector]]s, carbon monoxide detectors do not need to be placed near ceiling level. The use of carbon monoxide detectors has been standardized in many areas. In the US, NFPA 720-2009,{{cite book|title=NFPA 720: Standard for the Installation of Carbon Monoxide (CO) Detection and Warning Equipment|publisher=National Fire Protection Agency|location=Quincy, MA|year=2009|pages=|isbn=}} the carbon monoxide detector guidelines published by the [[National Fire Protection Association]], mandates the placement of carbon monoxide detectors/alarms on every level of the residence, including the basement, in addition to outside sleeping areas. In new homes, AC-powered detectors must have battery backup and be interconnected to ensure early warning of occupants at all levels. NFPA 720-2009 is the first national carbon monoxide standard to address devices in non-residential buildings. These guidelines, which now pertain to schools, healthcare centers, nursing homes and other non-residential buildings, include three main points: :1. A secondary power supply (battery backup) must operate all carbon monoxide notification appliances for at least 12 hours, :2. Detectors must be on the ceiling in the same room as permanently installed fuel-burning appliances, and :3. Detectors must be located on every habitable level and in every [[HVAC]] zone of the building. Gas organizations will often recommend to get gas appliances serviced at least once a year.{{cite web|title=Gas Safety in the Home |publisher=UK Gas Safe Register |accessdate=2013-05-27 |url=http://www.gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502012946/http://gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |archivedate=2013-05-02 |df= }} === Legal requirements === The NFPA standard is not necessarily enforced by law. As of April 2006, the US state of Massachusetts requires detectors to be present in all residences with potential CO sources, regardless of building age and whether they are owner-occupied or rented.{{cite web|url=http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|title=MGL Ch. 148 §28F{{frac|1|2}} – Nicole's Law, effective March 31, 2006|work=malegislature.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230154311/http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|archivedate=December 30, 2012|df=}} This is enforced by municipal inspectors, and was inspired by the death of 7-year-old Nicole Garofalo in 2005 due to snow blocking a home heating vent.{{cite web |url=http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305145343/http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |archivedate=2013-03-05 |df= }} Other jurisdictions may have no requirement or only mandate detectors for new construction or at time of sale. Despite similar deaths in vehicles with clogged exhaust pipes (for example in the [[Northeastern United States blizzard of 1978]] and [[February 2013 nor'easter]]) and the commercial availability of the equipment, there is no legal requirement for automotive CO detectors.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ===World Health Organization recommendations=== The following guideline values (ppm values rounded) and periods of time-weighted average exposures have been determined in such a way that the carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb) level of 2.5% is not exceeded, even when a normal subject engages in light or moderate exercise: * 100 mg/m3 (87 ppm) for 15 min * 60 mg/m3 (52 ppm) for 30 min * 30 mg/m3 (26 ppm) for 1 h * 10 mg/m3 (9 ppm) for 8 h For indoor air quality 7 mg/m3 (6 ppm) for 24 h (so as not to exceed 2% COHb for chronic exposure) == Treatment == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center;" |+ Time to remove 50% carboxy hemoglobin{{cite book|last1=Mathieu|first1=Daniel|title=Handbook on Hyperbaric Medicine|date=2006|publisher=Springer|location=[New York]|isbn=978-1402043765|edition=Online-Ausg.}} ! Oxygen pressure О2 ! Time |- |21% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (fresh air) | 5 hours 20 min |- |100% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (non-rebreather oxygen mask) | 1 hours 20 min |- |100% Hyperbaric oxygen (3 atmospheres absolute) | 23 min |} Initial treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning is to immediately remove the person from the exposure without endangering further people. Those who are unconscious may require [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on site. Administering [[oxygen]] via [[non-rebreather mask]] shortens the [[Biological half-life|half-life]] of carbon monoxide from 320 minutes, when breathing normal air, to only 80 minutes. Oxygen hastens the dissociation of carbon monoxide from [[carboxyhemoglobin]], thus turning it back into [[hemoglobin]].{{cite journal|author=Olson KR|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: Mechanisms, presentation, and controversies in management|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |volume=1|issue=3|pages=233–43|year=1984|pmid=6491241|doi=10.1016/0736-4679(84)90078-7}} Due to the possible severe effects in the fetus, pregnant women are treated with oxygen for longer periods of time than non-pregnant people.{{cite journal|author=Margulies JL|title=Acute carbon monoxide poisoning during pregnancy|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=4|issue=6|pages=516–19|date=November 1986|pmid=3778597|doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(86)80008-0}} === Hyperbaric oxygen === [[File:HyperBaric Oxygen Therapy Chamber 2008.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|A person within a hyperbaric oxygen chamber]] [[Hyperbaric oxygen]] is also used in the treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning, as it may hasten dissociation of CO from carboxyhemoglobin and cytochrome oxidase{{cite journal|vauthors=Brown DB, Mueller GL, Golich FC |title=Hyperbaric oxygen treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning in pregnancy: a case report|journal=Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine|volume=63|issue=11|pages=1011–14|date=November 1992|pmid=1445151}} to a greater extent than normal oxygen. Hyperbaric oxygen at three times [[atmospheric pressure]] reduces the half life of carbon monoxide to 23 (~80/3 minutes) minutes, compared to 80 minutes for oxygen at regular atmospheric pressure. It may also enhance oxygen transport to the tissues by plasma, partially bypassing the normal transfer through hemoglobin. However, it is controversial whether hyperbaric oxygen actually offers any extra benefits over normal high flow oxygen, in terms of increased survival or improved long-term outcomes.{{Cite journal|last=Buckley|first=Nick A.|last2=Juurlink|first2=David N.|last3=Isbister|first3=Geoff|last4=Bennett|first4=Michael H.|last5=Lavonas|first5=Eric J.|date=2011-04-13|title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|issue=4|page=CD002041|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002041.pub3|issn=1469-493X|pmid=21491385}}{{cite journal|author=Henry JA|title=Hyperbaric therapy for carbon monoxide poisoning: to treat or not to treat, that is the question|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=149–150|year=2005|pmid=16390211|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00002}} {{cite journal|author=Olson KR|title=Hyperbaric oxygen or normobaric oxygen?|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|page=151; discussion 159–60|year=2005|pmid=16390212|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00003}}{{cite journal|author=Seger D|title=The myth|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=155–56|year=2005|pmid=16390214|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00005}}{{cite journal|author=Thom SR|title=Hyperbaric oxygen therapy for carbon monoxide poisoning: Is it time to end the debates?|journal=Toxicological Reviews|volume=24|issue=3|pages=157–58|year=2005|pmid=16390215|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524030-00006}} There have been [[randomized controlled trial]]s in which the two treatment options have been compared;{{cite journal|vauthors=Scheinkestel CD, Bailey M, Myles PS, Jones K, Cooper DJ, Millar IL, Tuxen DV|title=Hyperbaric or normobaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning: a randomized controlled clinical trial|journal=[[The Medical Journal of Australia]]|date=March 1999|pages=203–10|volume=170|issue=5|pmid=10092916|url=http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/mar1/scheink/scheink.html|format=Free full text|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905012917/https://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/mar1/scheink/scheink.html|archivedate=2008-09-05|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Thom SR, Taber RL, Mendiguren II, Clark JM, Hardy KR, Fisher AB |title=Delayed neuropsychologic sequelae after carbon monoxide poisoning: prevention by treatment with hyperbaric oxygen|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|date=April 1995|pages=474–80|volume=25|issue=4|pmid=7710151|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(95)70261-X}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Raphael JC, Elkharrat D, Jars-Guincestre MC, Chastang C, Chasles V, Vercken JB, Gajdos P |title=Trial of normobaric and hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Lancet|date=August 1989|pages=414–19|volume=2|issue=8660|pmid=2569600|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(89)90592-8}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Ducasse JL, Celsis P, Marc-Vergnes JP|title=Non-comatose patients with acute carbon monoxide poisoning: hyperbaric or normobaric oxygenation?|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|date=March 1995|pages=9–15|volume=22|issue=1|pmid=7742714|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2193|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811174818/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2193|archivedate=2011-08-11|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Mathieu D, Mathieu-Nolf M, Durak C, Wattel F, Tempe JP, Bouachour G, Sainty JM|title=Randomized prospective study comparing the effect of HBO vs 12 hours NBO in non-comatose CO-poisoned patients: results of the preliminary analysis|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|year=1996|page=7|volume=23|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/447|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702235523/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/447|archivedate=2011-07-02|df=}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Weaver LK, Hopkins RO, Chan KJ, Churchill S, Elliott CG, Clemmer TP, Orme JF, Thomas FO, Morris AH |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=October 2002|pages=1057–67|volume=347|issue=14|pmid=12362006|doi=10.1056/NEJMoa013121}} of the six performed, four found hyperbaric oxygen improved outcome and two found no benefit for hyperbaric oxygen.{{cite journal|vauthors=Buckley NA, Isbister GK, Stokes B, Juurlink DN |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning: a systematic review and critical analysis of the evidence|journal=Toxicological Reviews|year=2005|pages=75–92|volume=24|issue=2|pmid=16180928|doi=10.2165/00139709-200524020-00002}} Some of these trials have been criticized for apparent flaws in their implementation.{{cite journal|author=Gorman DF.|title=Hyperbaric or normobaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning: a randomised controlled clinical trial. Unfortunate methodological flaws|journal=The Medical Journal of Australia|date=June 1999|pages=563; author reply 564–65|volume=170|issue=11|pmid=10397050}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Scheinkestel CD, Jones K, Myles PS, Cooper DJ, Millar IL, Tuxen DV |title=Where to now with carbon monoxide poisoning?|journal=Emergency Medicine Australasia: EMA|date=April 2004|pages=151–54|volume=16|issue=2|pmid=15239731|doi=10.1111/j.1742-6723.2004.00567.x}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Isbister GK, McGettigan P, Harris I |title=Hyperbaric oxygen for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=February 2003|pages=557–60|volume=348|issue=6|pmid=12572577|doi=10.1056/NEJM200302063480615}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Buckley NA, Juurlink DN |title=Carbon monoxide treatment guidelines must acknowledge the limitations of the existing evidence |journal=American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine |volume=187 |issue=12 |page=1390 |date=June 2013 |pmid=23767905 |doi=10.1164/rccm.201212-2262LE}} A review of all the literature concluded that the role of hyperbaric oxygen is unclear and the available evidence neither confirms nor denies a medically meaningful benefit. The authors suggested a large, well designed, externally audited, multicentre trial to compare normal oxygen with hyperbaric oxygen. === Other === Further treatment for other complications such as [[seizure]], hypotension, cardiac abnormalities, [[pulmonary edema]], and [[acidosis]] may be required. Increased muscle activity and seizures should be treated with [[dantrolene]] or [[diazepam]]; diazepam should only be given with appropriate respiratory support. Hypotension requires treatment with intravenous fluids; [[vasopressor]]s may be required to treat myocardial depression.{{cite journal|author=Tomaszewski C|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning. Early awareness and intervention can save lives|journal=Postgraduate Medicine|volume=105|issue=1|pages=39–40, 43–48, 50|date=January 1999|pmid=9924492|doi=10.3810/pgm.1999.01.496}} [[Cardiac dysrhythmia]]s are treated with standard [[advanced cardiac life support]] protocols. If severe, metabolic acidosis is treated with [[sodium bicarbonate]]. Treatment with sodium bicarbonate is controversial as acidosis may increase tissue oxygen availability.{{cite journal|author=Peirce EC|title=Treating acidemia in carbon monoxide poisoning may be dangerous|journal=Journal of Hyperbaric Medicine|volume=1|issue=2|pages=87–97|year=1986|pmid=|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/4304|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703000244/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/4304|archivedate=2011-07-03|df=}} Treatment of acidosis may only need to consist of oxygen therapy. The delayed development of neuropsychiatric impairment is one of the most serious complications of carbon monoxide poisoning. Brain damage is confirmed following [[magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] or [[X-ray computed tomography|CAT]] scans.{{cite journal|vauthors=Devine SA, Kirkley SM, Palumbo CL, White RF |title=MRI and neuropsychological correlates of carbon monoxide exposure: a case report |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=110 |issue=10 |pages=1051–55 |date=October 2002 |pmid=12361932 |pmc=1241033 |doi=10.1289/ehp.021101051 |url=http://ehpnet1.niehs.nih.gov/members/2002/110p1051-1055devine/devine-full.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707154535/http://ehpnet1.niehs.nih.gov/members/2002/110p1051-1055devine/devine-full.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-07 }}{{cite journal|vauthors=O'Donnell P, Buxton PJ, Pitkin A, Jarvis LJ |title=The magnetic resonance imaging appearances of the brain in acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Clinical Radiology|volume=55|issue=4|pages=273–80|date=April 2000|pmid=10767186|doi=10.1053/crad.1999.0369}} Extensive follow up and supportive treatment is often required for delayed neurological damage. Outcomes are often difficult to predict following poisoning,{{cite journal|vauthors=Seger D, Welch L |title=Carbon monoxide controversies: neuropsychologic testing, mechanism of toxicity, and hyperbaric oxygen|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=24|issue=2|pages=242–48|date=August 1994|pmid=8037390|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(94)70136-9}} especially people who have symptoms of [[cardiac arrest]], [[coma]], [[metabolic acidosis]], or have high carboxyhemoglobin levels. One study reported that approximately 30% of people with severe carbon monoxide poisoning will have a fatal outcome. It has been reported that electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may increase the likelihood of delayed neuropsychiatric sequelae (DNS) after carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.{{cite journal|last=Chiang|first=CL|author2=Tseng, MC|title=Safe use of electroconvulsive therapy in a highly suicidal survivor of carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Gen Hosp Psychiatry|date=27 September 2011}} == Epidemiology == {{Category see also|Deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning}} The true number of cases of carbon monoxide poisoning is unknown, since many non-lethal exposures go undetected. From the available data, carbon monoxide poisoning is the most common cause of injury and death due to poisoning worldwide.{{cite journal|author=Thom SR|title=Hyperbaric-oxygen therapy for acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=347|issue=14|pages=1105–06|date=October 2002|pmid=12362013|doi=10.1056/NEJMe020103}} Poisoning is typically more common during the winter months.{{cite journal |vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=339 |issue=22 |pages=1603–08 |date=November 1998 |pmid=9828249 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206}}{{cite journal |author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) |title=Deaths from motor-vehicle-related unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning—Colorado, 1996, New Mexico, 1980–1995, and United States, 1979–1992 |journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report |volume=45 |issue=47 |pages=1029–32 |date=November 1996 |pmid=8965803 |doi= |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/00044617.htm |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624012603/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00044617.htm |archivedate=2017-06-24 |df= }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Partrick M, Fiesseler F, Shih R, Riggs R, Hung O |title=Monthly variations in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide exposures in the emergency department |journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=161–67 |year=2009 |pmid=19860138}} This is due to increased domestic use of gas furnaces, gas or kerosene [[space heater]]s, and kitchen stoves during the winter months, which if faulty and/or used without adequate ventilation, may produce excessive carbon monoxide.{{cite journal |author=Heckerling PS |title=Occult carbon monoxide poisoning: a cause of winter headache |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=201–04 |date=May 1987 |pmid=3580051 |doi= 10.1016/0735-6757(87)90320-2|url=}} Carbon monoxide detection and poisoning also increases during power outages, when electric heating and cooking appliances become inoperative and residents may temporarily resort to fuel-burning space heaters, stoves, and grills (some of which are safe only for outdoor use but nonetheless are errantly burned indoors).{{cite web|title=Department of Public Health Warns of Dangers of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning During Power Outages|url=http://www.towergenerator.com/Resources/Power_Generator_Carbon_Monoxide_Dangers/|publisher=Tower Generator|accessdate=2011-11-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426001248/http://www.towergenerator.com/Resources/Power_Generator_Carbon_Monoxide_Dangers/|archivedate=2012-04-26|df=}}{{cite web|title=Avoiding Carbon Monoxide poisoning during a power outage |url=http://www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/psa/co.asp |publisher=CDC |accessdate=2011-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111212171534/http://www.bt.cdc.gov/disasters/psa/co.asp |archivedate=2011-12-12 |df= }}{{cite journal|last=Klein|first=Kelly|author2=Herzog, Perri |author3=Smolinske, Susan |author4= White, Suzanne |title=Demand for poison control center services "surged" during the 2003 blackout.|journal=Clinical Toxicology|year=2007|volume=45|issue=3|pages=248–54|doi=10.1080/15563650601031676 |pmid=17453875}} It has been estimated that more than 40,000 people per year seek medical attention for carbon monoxide poisoning in the United States.{{cite journal|author=Hampson NB|title=Emergency department visits for carbon monoxide poisoning in the Pacific Northwest|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |date=September 1998|pages=695–98|volume=16|issue=5|pmid=9752939|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(98)00080-8}} 95% of carbon monoxide poisoning deaths in the United States are due to gas space heaters.{{cite web|url=http://www.esv.vic.gov.au/Portals/0/About%20ESV/Files/Gas%20use%20reports/2004AddendumtoOverseasandAustralianStatisticsandBenchmarksforCustomerGasSafetyIncidents.pdf|title=2004 Addendum to Overseas and Australian Statistics and Benchmarks for Customer Gas Safety Incidents|publisher=Office of Gas Safety, Victoria|year=2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924002528/http://www.esv.vic.gov.au/Portals/0/About%20ESV/Files/Gas%20use%20reports/2004AddendumtoOverseasandAustralianStatisticsandBenchmarksforCustomerGasSafetyIncidents.pdf|archivedate=2015-09-24|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scer.gov.au/files/2012/03/EMR2-QRA-Final.pdf |title=The risk of carbon monoxide poisoning from domestic gas appliances |work=Report to the Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism |date=Feb 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312065135/http://www.scer.gov.au/files/2012/03/EMR2-QRA-Final.pdf |archivedate=2015-03-12 |df= }} In many industrialized countries carbon monoxide is the cause of more than 50% of fatal poisonings. In the United States, approximately 200 people die each year from carbon monoxide poisoning associated with home fuel-burning heating equipment.{{cite web|title=Carbon Monoxide Detectors Can Save Lives: CPSC Document #5010|publisher=US Consumer Product Safety Commission|url=http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PUBS/5010.html|accessdate=2009-04-30|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090409030219/http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PUBS/5010.html |archivedate=2009-04-09}} Carbon monoxide poisoning contributes to the approximately 5613 smoke inhalation deaths each year in the United States.{{cite journal|vauthors=Cobb N, Etzel RA|title=Unintentional carbon monoxide-related deaths in the United States, 1979 through 1988|journal=JAMA|volume=266|issue=5|pages=659–63|date=August 7, 1991|pmid=1712865|url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/266/5/659|doi=10.1001/jama.266.5.659|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921102448/http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/abstract/266/5/659|archivedate=September 21, 2008|df=}} The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] reports, "Each year, more than 500 Americans die from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning, and more than 2,000 commit suicide by intentionally poisoning themselves."{{cite web|title=Carbon Monoxide poisoning fact sheet|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|date=July 2006|url=https://www.cdc.gov/co/pdfs/faqs.pdf|format=pdf|doi=|accessdate=2008-12-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218085439/http://www.cdc.gov/co/pdfs/faqs.pdf|archivedate=2008-12-18|df=}} For the 10-year period from 1979 to 1988, 56,133 deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning occurred in the United States, with 25,889 of those being suicides, leaving 30,244 unintentional deaths. A report from [[New Zealand]] showed that 206 people died from carbon monoxide poisoning in the years of 2001 and 2002. In total carbon monoxide poisoning was responsible for 43.9% of deaths by poisoning in that country.{{cite journal|vauthors=McDowell R, Fowles J, Phillips D|title=Deaths from poisoning in New Zealand: 2001–2002|journal=[[The New Zealand Medical Journal]]|volume=118|issue=1225|page=U1725|date=November 2005|pmid=16286939|url=http://www.nzmj.com/journal/118-1225/1725/|format=Free full text|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110714220921/http://www.nzmj.com/journal/118-1225/1725/|archivedate=2011-07-14|df=}} In [[South Korea]], 1,950 people had been poisoned by carbon monoxide with 254 deaths from 2001 through 2003.{{cite journal|vauthors=Song KJ, Shin SD, Cone DC |title=Socioeconomic status and severity-based incidence of poisoning: a nationwide cohort study|journal=[[Clinical Toxicology]]|volume=47|issue=8|pages=818–26|date=September 2009|pmid=19640232|doi=10.1080/15563650903158870}} A report from [[Jerusalem]] showed 3.53 per 100,000 people were poisoned annually from 2001 through 2006.{{cite journal|vauthors=Salameh S, Amitai Y, Antopolsky M, Rott D, Stalnicowicz R |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning in Jerusalem: epidemiology and risk factors|journal=Clinical Toxicology|volume=47|issue=2|pages=137–41|date=February 2009|pmid=18720104|doi=10.1080/15563650801986711}} In [[Hubei]], China, 218 deaths from poisoning were reported over a 10-year period with 16.5% being from carbon monoxide exposure.{{cite journal |vauthors=Liu Q, Zhou L, Zheng N, Zhuo L, Liu Y, Liu L |title=Poisoning deaths in China: type and prevalence detected at the Tongji Forensic Medical Center in Hubei |journal=Forensic Science International |volume=193 |issue=1–3 |pages=88–94 |date=December 2009 |pmid=19854011 |doi=10.1016/j.forsciint.2009.09.013}} ==History== The earliest description of carbon monoxide poisoning dates to at least 200 BC by [[Aristotle]]. Documented cases of carbon monoxide being used as a [[Suicide methods#Carbon monoxide|method of suicide]] date to at least 100 BC in [[ancient Rome]].{{cite book|last1=Penney|first1=David G.|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|date=2007|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0849384189|page=754|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA754|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910172025/https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA754|archivedate=2017-09-10|df=}} In the AD 350s, the Roman emperor [[Julian (emperor)|Julian]] suffered from carbon monoxide poisoning in Paris, and later described it in his work ''Misopogon'': "though the winter weather prevailed and continually increased in severity, even so I did not allow my servants to heat the house, because I was afraid of drawing out the dampness in the walls; but I ordered them to carry in fire that had burned down and to place in the room a very moderate number of hot coals. But the coals, though there were not very many of them, brought out from the walls quantities of steam and this made me fall asleep. And since my head was filled with the fumes I was almost choked. Then I was carried outside."Julian, ''Misopogon'' 341C-D This misunderstanding of the causes of carbon monoxide poisoning may have caused the death of Julian's successor, [[Jovian (emperor)|Jovian]]. [[John Scott Haldane]] identified carbon monoxide as the lethal constituent of [[afterdamp]], the gas created by [[combustion]], after examining many bodies of miners killed in pit explosions. Their skin was coloured cherry-pink from [[carboxyhaemoglobin]], the stable compound formed in the blood by reaction with the gas. As a result of his research, he was able to design respirators for rescue workers. He tested the effect of carbon monoxide on his own body in a closed chamber, describing the results of his slow poisoning. In the late 1890s, he introduced the use of small animals for miners to detect dangerous levels of carbon monoxide underground, either white mice or canaries. With a faster metabolism, they showed the effects of poisoning before gas levels became critical for the workers, and so gave an early warning of the problem. The [[canary in a coal mine|canary]] in British pits was replaced in 1986 by the electronic gas detector. As part of the [[Holocaust]] during [[World War II]], German [[Nazi]]s used [[gas van]]s at [[Chelmno extermination camp]] and elsewhere to kill an estimated over 700,000 prisoners by carbon monoxide poisoning. This method was also used in the gas chambers of several [[extermination camp|death camps]] such as [[Treblinka]], [[Sobibor]] and [[Belzec]]. Gassing with carbon monoxide started in [[action T4]], the programme developed by the Nazis in Germany to murder the mentally ill and [[disabled people]] before the war started in earnest. The gas was supplied by [[IG Farben]] in pressurized cylinders and fed by tubes into the gas chambers built at various mental hospitals, such as [[Hartheim Euthanasia Centre]]. Many key personnel were recruited from the T4 programme to murder much larger numbers of people in the gas vans and the special [[gas chamber]]s used in the [[death camp]]s such as [[Treblinka]]. [[Exhaust fumes]] from tank engines for example, were used to supply the gas to the chambers.{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Genocide|vauthors=Totten S, Bartrop P, Markusen E|year=2007|publisher=Greenwood|pages=129, 156|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rgGA91skoP4C&lpg=PA156&dq=nazi%20carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&f=false|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526000146/http://books.google.com/books?id=rgGA91skoP4C&lpg=PA156&ots=S8jhBY6NxB&dq=nazi%20carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=carbon%20monoxide%20poisoning&f=false|archivedate=2013-05-26|df=|isbn=978-0313346422}} The use of oxygen as treatment began in 1868. The use of hyperbaric oxygen in rats following poisoning was studied by Haldane in 1895 while its use in humans began in the 1960s. ==Research== Carbon monoxide is produced naturally by the body as a byproduct of converting [[protoporphyrin]] into [[bilirubin]]. This carbon monoxide also combines with hemoglobin to make carboxyhemoglobin, but not at toxic levels. Small amounts of CO are beneficial and enzymes exist that produce it at times of oxidative stress. Drugs are being developed to introduce small amounts of CO during certain kinds of surgery, these drugs are called [[carbon monoxide-releasing molecules]].{{cite journal|last1=Foresti|first1=R|last2=Bani-Hani|first2=MG|last3=Motterlini|first3=R|title=Use of carbon monoxide as a therapeutic agent: promises and challenges.|journal=Intensive Care Medicine|date=April 2008|volume=34|issue=4|pages=649–58|pmid=18286265|doi=10.1007/s00134-008-1011-1}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|T|58}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|986}} | eMedicineSubj = article | eMedicineTopic = 819987 | MeshID = D002249 }} * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co-comp/ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) – Carbon Monoxide – NIOSH Workplace Safety and Health Topic] * International Programme on Chemical Safety (1999). [http://www.who.int/ipcs/publications/ehc/ehc_213/en/ Carbon Monoxide], Environmental Health Criteria 213, Geneva: WHO {{Poisoning and toxicity}} {{good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carbon Monoxide Poisoning}} [[Category:Carbon monoxide|Poisoning]] [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Industrial hygiene]] [[Category:Medical emergencies]] [[Category:Natural gas safety]] [[Category:Suicide methods]] [[Category:Toxic effects of substances chiefly nonmedicinal as to source]] [[Category:RTT]] [[Category:RTTEM]]

revision.comment: /* 1847 */ [[Crime and Outrage Bill (Ireland) 1847]] is curiously absent
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{main|Great Famine (Ireland)}} [[File:Irish potato famine Bridget O'Donnel.jpg|thumb|An 1849 depiction of Bridget O'Donnell and her two children during the famine.]] The '''Chronology of the Great Famine''' ({{lang-ga|'''An Gorta Mór'''}}<ref>The term has appeared in the titles of numerous books on the event, as demonstrated by [http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=%22Gorta+Mo%CC%81r%22&=Search&qt=results_page this search on WorldCat]</ref> or ''An Drochshaol'', litt: ''The Bad Life'') documents a period of Irish history between 1845 and 1852<ref>Kinealy (1995), xvi–ii.</ref> during which time the population of Ireland was reduced by 20 to 25 percent.<ref>Christine Kinealy, This Great Calamity, Gill & Macmillan (1994), {{ISBN|0-7171-4011-3}}, 357.</ref> The [[proximate cause]] was [[famine]] resulting from a potato disease commonly known as [[late blight]].<ref>Cormac Ó Gráda, ''Ireland's Great Famine: Interdisciplinary Perspectives'', Dublin: University College Dublin Press, 2006, p. 7. {{ISBN|1-904558-57-7}}</ref> Although blight ravaged potato crops throughout Europe during the 1840s, the impact and human cost in Ireland{{spaced ndash}}where a third of the population was entirely dependent on the potato for food{{spaced ndash}}was exacerbated by a host of political, social and economic factors which remain the subject of historical debate.
An important and controversial point of debate, that is notable amongst Irish people, was that Irish food supplies were sufficient until it was taken away by the British the feed the British, and the landlords kept economic benefits to themselves. Some commentators and writers controversially compared this explanation to "genocide".
<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith, ''The Great Hunger'', Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1991, p. 19. {{ISBN|978-0-14-014515-1}}</ref><ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity'', Gill & Macmillan, 1994, pp. xvi–ii, 2–3. {{ISBN|0-7171-4011-3}}</ref>
== Chronology ==
===1845===
====August==== At the beginning of August, [[Robert Peel|Sir Robert Peel]], the British Prime Minister, received news of a potato disease in the South of England. This was the first recorded evidence that the 'blight' which had ravaged the potato crop in North America in 1843-1844 had crossed the Atlantic. Cecil Woodham-Smith would write that a failure in England would be serious, but for Ireland, it would be a disaster.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 39</ref>
====September==== Following earlier reports of incidences of the blight in England, on 13 September 1845 <ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity'', Gill & Macmillan, 1994, {{ISBN|0-7171-4011-3}} pg.32 put the date at the 16th</ref> potato blight was first reported in Ireland. The crops at Dublin were suddenly perishing, it was reported in the ''Gardeners' Chronicle'', asking "where will Ireland be in the event of a universal potato rot?" The British Government were nevertheless optimistic through the next few weeks.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 39–40</ref>
====October==== [[File:Skibbereen by James Mahony, 1847.JPG|thumb|[[Skibbereen]] 1847 by [[Cork (city)|Cork]] artist [[James Mahony]] (1810–1879), commissioned by the ''[[Illustrated London News]]'']] *As soon as digging of potato crops began, devastating reports started coming in. Sir Robert Peel found the accounts 'very alarming' and writing to Sir James Graham, the Home Secretary on 13 October reminded him that there was always a tendency in Irish news to exaggerate.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.41</ref> Constabulary Reports from the 15 reported great failures, Sir James Graham, the Home Secretary wrote that the truth about the potato crop, until digging was completed, could not be fully ascertained.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.42</ref> *The Prime Minister [[Robert Peel]] was prompted to act,<ref>''The Course of Irish History'' (1994) edited by T.W.Moody and F.X.Martin. Page 268. Mercier Press. {{ISBN|1-85635-108-4}}.</ref> and on 15 October he decided to summon an emergency meeting of his Cabinet for 31 October. The remedy he decided was to repeal the [[Corn Laws]].<ref name="cws-p50">Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.50</ref> Peel then decided to set up a Scientific Commission to go to Ireland and investigate the potato blight and report on conditions.<ref>James S. Donnelly, Jr, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing 2005, UK, {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}} pg.44</ref><ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.44</ref> *The emergency Cabinet meeting met on 31 October till 1 November. The first day consisted of reading reports and memoranda from Ireland on the potato failure. Peel proposed that a relief commission be established in Ireland, and a sum of money be advanced to the Lord -Lieutenant. Differences arose when Peel pointed out that these measures required an advance of public money. The purchase of food for destitute districts would open the question of [[Corn Laws]]. Was it possible, it was asked, to vote public money for the sustenance of a people on account of "actual or apprehended scarcity" and still maintain restrictions on the free import of grain; Peel declared it was not.<ref name="cws-p51">Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.51</ref> On this issue then the Cabinet split, the overwhelming majority voting against Peel.<ref>Cormac Ó Gráda, Ireland's Great Famine: Interdisciplinary Perspectives, Dublin: University College Dublin Press, 2006, p. 7. {{ISBN|1-904558-57-7}} pg.15</ref> Unable to reach a decision, the Cabinet adjourned till 6 November.<ref name="cws-p51"/>
The principle of the Corn Laws had been to keep the price of home-grown grain up. Duties on imported grain assured English farmers a minimum and profitable price. The burden of a higher price for bread was carried by the labouring classes, in particular factory workers and operatives. It was claimed that if the Corn Laws were repealed all those connected with the land would be ruined and the established social organisation of the country destroyed.<ref name="cws-p50"/>
According to Cecil Woodham-Smith, the rising wrath of Tories and landlords ensured "all interest in Ireland was submerged." She writes that the Tory Mayor of Liverpool refused to call a meeting for the relief of Irish distress. She continues that the [[Mansion House Committee]] in Dublin was accused of 'deluding the public with a false alarm', and the blight itself 'was represented as the invention of agitators on the other side of the water'. The entanglement of the Irish famine with the repeal of the Corn Laws, she says, was a key misfortune for Ireland. The potato failure was eclipsed by the domestic issue of Corn Law repeal. The Irish famine, she writes, "slipped into the background."<ref name="cws-p50"/>
====November====
*On 9–10 November<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 54</ref> Peel ordered the secret purchase of £100,000 worth of [[Maize|Indian corn]] and meal from America for distribution in Ireland.<ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52'', Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg.38, 46</ref><ref>James S. Donnelly, Jr, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing 2005, UK, {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}} pg.49</ref> *On 15 November the Scientific Commissioners reported that half the potato crop had been destroyed.<ref name="cws-p51"/> *On 19 November the Mansion House Committee in Dublin claimed to have "ascertained beyond the shadow of doubt that considerably more than one-third of the entire potato crop...has been already destroyed."<ref>James S. Donnelly, Jr, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing 2005, UK, {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}} pg.43</ref> *On 20 November the Relief Commission first met.<ref>Christine Kinealy, This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52, Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg. 41</ref><ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 57</ref> *Unable to persuade his Cabinet to repeal the Corn Laws, on 5 December Peel tendered his resignation <ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52'', Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg.37</ref> to Queen Victoria but was reinstated days later when [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|Lord John Russell]] was unable to form a government.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 52</ref>
===1846=== The first deaths from hunger took place in early 1846.<ref>Thomas Keneally (1999) ''The Great Shame''. London: Vintage: 110</ref> In March Peel set up a programme of public works in Ireland but was forced to resign as Prime Minister on 29 June.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 78–86</ref> The new Whig administration under [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|Lord Russell]], influenced by their [[laissez-faire]] belief that the market would provide the food needed<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 408–11</ref> then halted government food and relief works, leaving many hundreds of thousands of people without any work, money or food.<ref name="david2002">David Ross (2002) ''Ireland: History of a Nation'': 224, 311</ref> Grain continued to be exported from the country.<ref name="david2002"/> Private initiatives such as The Central Relief Committee of the Society of Friends (Quakers) attempted to fill the gap caused by the end of government relief and eventually the government reinstated the relief works, although bureaucracy slowed the release of food supplies.<ref name="david2002"/> The blight almost totally destroyed the 1846 crop and the Famine worsened considerably.<ref name="david2002"/> By December a third of a million destitute people were employed in public works.<ref>David Ross (2002) ''Ireland: History of a Nation'': 311</ref>
===1847=== [[File:Emigrants Leave Ireland by Henry Doyle 1868.jpg|thumb|''Emigrants Leave Ireland'', engraving by Henry Doyle (1827–1892), from Mary Frances Cusack's Illustrated History of Ireland, 1868]] There were average crop yields in the 1847 harvest, but due to lack of seed potatoes to plant, the crop was low.<ref>Líam Kennedy, Paul S. Ell, E. M. Crawford & L. A. Clarkson, Mapping The Great Irish Famine, Four Courts Press, 1999, {{ISBN|1-85182-353-0}} pg.69</ref> Crowds began to throng the public works during the last months of 1846 and the start of 1847, which promoted exactly the social conditions for the spread of 'famine fever.'<ref>James S. Donnelly, JR, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing (UK 2005 RP), {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}}, pg.173</ref> In late January and February, legislation called the Temporary Relief Act went through the British parliament; it became popularly known as the Soup Kitchen Act and occasionally as Burgoyne's Act.<ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52'', Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg 136</ref> This system of relief was designed to deliver cheap food directly and gratuitously to the destitute masses. This system of relief would be terminated in September.<ref>James S. Donnelly, JR, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing (UK 2005 RP), {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}}, pg. 81–85</ref> The government also announced an additional change in the system of relief. After August 1847, the permanent Poor Law was to be extended and was to become responsible for providing relief and as a result, all relief would be financed by the local Poor Law rates.<ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52'', Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg 137</ref> This put impossible loads on local poor rates, particularly in the rural west and south.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 174–187</ref> With the mass emigration of the famine era, the horrors of the '[[coffin ships]]' and 1847 have ever since been associated in the popular mind, according to James S. Donnelly.<ref>James S. Donnelly, JR, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing (UK 2005 RP), {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}}, pg.179</ref>
In December 1847 The [[Crime and Outrage Bill (Ireland) 1847]] was enacted due to growing Irish nationalist agitation that was causing the British government concern about a possible [[Young Irelander Rebellion of 1848|violent rebellion]] against British rule in Ireland.<ref>Woodham-Smith, Cecil [[The Great Hunger]] Ireland1845 1849 Harper and Row New york pages 326-327</ref>
The bill gave the [[Lord Lieutenant of Ireland]] the power to organise the island into districts and bring police forces into them at the districts' expense. It limited who could own guns, and required all of the men in the district between the ages of 16 and 60 to assist in apprehending suspected murderers when landlords were killed, or else be guilty of a misdemeanour themselves.
===1848=== The blight returned in 1848 and outbreaks of cholera were reported.<ref name="david20022002"/> Evictions became common among the Irish who could not keep up with the demands of their British landlords. Famine victims on outdoor relief peaked in July at almost 840,000 people.<ref name="david20022002"/> On 29 July [[Young Irelander Rebellion of 1848|an uprising against the government]] was led by [[William Smith O'Brien]]. After a skirmish at "[[Famine Warhouse 1848|Widow McCormack's house]]" in the village of [[Ballingarry, South Tipperary|Ballingarry]], [[County Tipperary]] the leaders of the rebellion fled to America or were sentenced to transportation.<ref name="david20022002"/><ref>Robert Kee (2000) ''The Green Flag: A History of Irish Nationalism'': 270-89</ref>
===1849=== The potato crop failed again in 1849 and famine was accompanied by cholera outbreaks.<ref name="david20022002"/> This deadly cholera epidemic killed one of Ireland's greatest poets: [[James Clarence Mangan]].<ref name="david20022002"/>
===1850=== The Famine ended.<ref name="david20022002">David Ross (2002) ''Ireland: History of a Nation'': 313</ref>
===1851=== By 1851 census figures showed that the population of Ireland had fallen to 6,575,000 – a drop of 1,600,000 in ten years.<ref name="david20022002"/> Cormac Ó Gráda and Joel Mokyr have described the 1851 census as a famous but flawed source. They contend that the combination of institutional and individuals figures gives "an incomplete and biased count" of fatalities during the famine.<ref name="cormac2006">Cormac Ó Gráda, Ireland’s Great Famine: Interdisciplinary Perspectives, University College Dublin Press, 2006, {{ISBN|1-904558-57-7}} pg. 3</ref> The famine left in its wake up to a million dead and another million emigrated.<ref>David Ross (2002) ''Ireland: History of a Nation'': 226</ref> The famine caused a sense of lasting bitterness by the Irish towards the British government, whom many blamed — then and now — for the starvation of so many people.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 412–13</ref> The fall-out of the famine continued for decades afterwards.
==See also== {{Commons category|Potato famine of Ireland}} * [[Irish Famine (1740–41)]] * [[Irish Famine (1879)]] * [[Legacy of the Great Irish Famine]] (continuation of this article) * [[Highland Potato Famine]] (1846–57) (agrarian crisis in Scotland at the same time) * [[European Potato Failure]] (the wider agrarian crisis in Europe at the same time) * [[List of natural disasters in the British Isles]] * "[[The Fields of Athenry]]," a popular song about the famine * [[List of famines]] * [[Holodomor]], a 1930s famine in [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukraine]], the causes of which are also the subject of debate
==Further reading== *[[Mary E. Daly]], ''The Famine in Ireland'' *[[R. Dudley Edwards]] and [[T. Desmond Williams]] (eds.), ''The Great Famine: Studies in Irish history 1845–52'' *[[Peter Gray (historian)|Peter Gray]], ''The Irish Famine'' *"An Argument that the Irish Famine was genocide"[http://www.irishhistorylinks.net/History_Links/IrishFamineGenocide.html] *[[Joseph O'Connor]], ''Star of the Sea'' *[[Cormac Ó Gráda]], ''An Economic History of Ireland'' *[[Cormac Ó Gráda]], ''Black '47 and Beyond'' *[[Robert Kee]], ''Ireland: A History'' ({{ISBN|0349106789}}) *[[Christine Kinealy]], ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845 – 1852''[http://www.history.ac.uk/ihr/Focus/Victorians/clarkson.html] *[[John Mitchel]], ''The Last Conquest of Ireland'' (1861) (University College Dublin Press reprint, 2005 paperback) ISBN I-904558-36-4 *[[Cecil Woodham-Smith]], ''The Great Hunger, 1845–49'' (Penguin, 1991 edition) *[[Marita Conlon-McKenna]], ''[[Under the Hawthorn Tree (novel)|Under the Hawthorn Tree]]'' *[[Thomas Gallagher (author)|Thomas Gallagher]], ''Paddy's Lament, Ireland 1846–1847: Prelude to Hatred'' *[[Canon John O'Rourke]], ''The Great Irish Famine'' ({{ISBN|1853900494}} Hardback) ({{ISBN|185390130X}} Paperback) Veritas Publications 1989. First published in 1874. *[[Liam O'Flaherty]], ''Famine'' *Colm Tóibín and Diarmaid Ferriter, [[The Irish Famine (book)|''The Irish Famine'']], {{ISBN|1-86197-249-0}} / 9781861972491 (first edition, hardback) *[[Kevin Baker (author)|Kevin Baker]], ''Paradise Alley'' *Several [[Young Ireland#Books By Young Irelanders .28Irish Confederation.29|books by Young Irelanders]] make reference to the Great Irish Famine
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== {{refbegin}} * [[Norman Gash|Gash, Norman]]. ''Mr. Secretary Peel: The Life of Sir Robert Peel to 1830.'' Longmans: London, 1961. * Kinealy, Christine. ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52''. Gill & Macmillan: 1995. {{ISBN|1-57098-034-9}}. * [[Cecil Woodham-Smith|Woodham-Smith, Cecil]]. ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845–1849.'' Signet: New York, 1964. {{refend}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20000818232008/http://www.nde.state.ne.us/SS/irish/irish_pf.html New Jersey Commission on Holocaust Education 1996] *[http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/14412 The History of the Irish Famine by Rev. John O'Rourke] *[http://www.nationalarchives.ie/topics/famine/famine.html Irish National Archives information on the Famine] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051103000213/http://www.thegreathunger.org/ Quinnipiac University's An Gorta Mor site – includes etexts] *[http://eh.net/encyclopedia/ograda.famine.php Ireland's Great Famine] (Cormac Ó Gráda) from EH.Net Encyclopedia of Economic History *[http://www.irishholocaust.org/ Irish Holocaust] *[http://www.american.edu/TED/potato.htm History] *[http://pubs.socialistreviewindex.org.uk/sr189/stack.htm Ireland: The hunger years 1845–1851] *[http://www.irishpotatofamine.org/ Kids History Website about the Famine] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060622103532/http://multitext.ucc.ie/d/Famine Cork Multitext Project article on the Famine, by Donnchadh Ó Corráin] *For more on the pathogen see http://botit.botany.wisc.edu/toms_fungi/mar2001.html *Karp, Ivan. Museum Frictions: Public Cultures/Global Transformations. [https://books.google.com/books?id=sk3o1irXY5oC&pg=PA400&dq=%22irish+holocaust%22&ei=dcP5RrW1II_g6wKSzsDeAQ&sig=UNoCD7Yv1Fp50hUKr25mj1gOSUw] *[[Seamus Metress|Seamus P. Metress]], Richard A. Rajner. The Great Starvation: An Irish Holocaust. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Q3crAAAACAAJ&dq=%22irish+holocaust%22&ei=dcP5RrW1II_g6wKSzsDeAQ] *[https://books.google.com/books?q=%22irish+holocaust%22] *[http://www.uwm.edu/~michael/choctaw/retrace.html Irish Repay Choctaw Famine Gift:March Traces Trail of Tears in Trek for Somalian Relief] *[http://www.uwm.edu/~michael/choctaw/robinson.html President of Ireland Mary Robinson Addresses the Choctaw People] *[http://www.thompsontrading.co.uk/DAYSOFHUNGER.htm Clips and dvds of the Irish Potato Famine] *[http://viewsofthefamine.wordpress.com/ Views of the Famine] * http://www.sligoheritage.com/archive.htm Famine on the Gore-Booth and Palmerston estates in Sligo, Ireland * [http://www.doonbleisce.com/famine_in_doon.htm The Famine in Doon co.Limerick]
{{Great Hunger}}

revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/206.116.23.41|206.116.23.41]] ([[User talk:206.116.23.41|talk]]): No point in breaking that out. Please discuss this on the talk page before trying again. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{short description|The history and future of the universe according to Big Bang cosmology}} {{see also|Timeline of the formation of the Universe}} {{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} [[File:CMB Timeline300 no WMAP.jpg|thumb|upright=2|Diagram of evolution of the (observable part) of the universe from the Big Bang (left) to the present]] {{Physical cosmology}} {{Nature timeline}} The '''chronology of the universe''' describes the history and [[future of the universe]] according to [[Big Bang]] cosmology. The earliest stages of the universe's existence are estimated as taking place 13.8 [[billion years]] ago, with an [[confidence level|uncertainty]] of around 21 million years at the 68% confidence level. The [[Planck (spacecraft)#2015 data release|Planck Collaboration]] in 2015 published the estimate of 13.799 ± 0.021 billion years ago (68% confidence interval). See Table 4 on page 31 of pdf. {{Cite journal |author=Planck Collaboration |date=2015 |title=Planck 2015 results. XIII. Cosmological parameters |journal=[[Astronomy & Astrophysics]] |volume=594 |issue=13 |pages=A13 |arxiv=1502.01589 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201525830 |bibcode=2016A&A...594A..13P }} ==Outline== For the purposes of this summary, it is convenient to divide the chronology of the universe since it [[Cosmogony|originated]], into five parts. It is generally considered meaningless or unclear whether [[time]] existed before this chronology: :'''1. The [[#Very early universe|very early universe]]''' – the first [[picosecond]] (10−12) of cosmic time. It includes the [[Planck epoch]], during which currently understood [[laws of physics]] may not apply; the emergence in stages of the four known [[fundamental interaction]]s or [[force]]s – first [[gravity]], and later the [[strong interaction|strong]], [[weak interaction|weak]] and [[electromagnetic interaction|electromagnetic]] interactions; and the [[metric expansion of space|expansion of space]] and [[supercooling]] of the still immensely hot universe due to [[cosmic inflation]], which is believed to have been triggered by the separation of the [[Strong interaction|strong]] and [[electroweak interaction]]. :Tiny ripples in the universe at this stage are believed to be the basis of large-scale structures that formed much later. Different stages of the very early universe are understood to different extents. The earlier parts are beyond the grasp of practical experiments in [[particle physics]] but can be explored through other means. :'''2. The [[#Early universe|early universe]]''', lasting around 377,000 years. Initially, various kinds of [[subatomic particle]]s are formed in stages. These particles include almost equal amounts of [[matter]] and [[antimatter]], so most of it quickly annihilates, leaving a small excess of matter in the universe. :At about one second, [[Neutrino decoupling|neutrinos decouple]]; these neutrinos form the [[cosmic neutrino background]]. If [[primordial black hole]]s exist, they are also formed at about one second of cosmic time. [[Composite particle|Composite]] [[subatomic particle]]s emerge – including [[proton]]s and [[neutron]]s – and from about 3 minutes, conditions are suitable for [[nucleosynthesis]]: around 25% of the protons and all the neutrons [[nuclear fusion|fuse]] [[big bang nucleosynthesis|into heavier elements]], mainly [[helium-4]]. :By 20 minutes, the universe is no longer hot enough for fusion, but far too hot for neutral [[atom]]s to exist or [[photon]]s to travel far. It is therefore an [[Opacity (optics)|opaque]] [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]]. At around 47,000 years,Ryden, Barbara, "Introduction to Cosmology", 2006, eqn. 6.33, 6.41 as the universe cools, its behavior begins to be dominated by [[matter]] rather than radiation. :At about 377,000 years {{citation needed|date=November 2018}}, the universe finally becomes cool enough for neutral [[atom]]s to form ("[[Recombination (cosmology)|recombination]]"), and as a result it also became [[Transparency and translucency|transparent]] for the first time. The newly formed atoms – mainly [[hydrogen]] and [[helium]] with traces of [[lithium]] – quickly reach their lowest energy state ([[ground state]]) by releasing photons ("[[decoupling (cosmology)|photon decoupling]]"), and these photons can still be detected today as the [[cosmic microwave background]] (CMB). This is currently the oldest observation we have of the universe. :'''3. Dark Ages and large-scale [[structure formation|structure emergence]]''', from 377,000 years until about 1 billion years. After [[recombination (cosmology)|recombination]] and [[decoupling (cosmology)|decoupling]], the universe was transparent but the clouds of [[hydrogen]] only collapsed very slowly to form [[star]]s and [[galaxy|galaxies]], so there were no new sources of light. The only photons (electromagnetic radiation, or "light") in the universe were those released during decoupling (visible today as the [[cosmic microwave background]]) and [[hydrogen line|21 cm radio emissions]] occasionally emitted by hydrogen atoms. The decoupled photons would have filled the universe with a brilliant pale orange glow at first, gradually [[redshift]]ing to non-visible [[wavelength]]s after about 3 million years, leaving it without visible light. This period is known as the [[Dark Ages (cosmology)|Dark Ages]]. :Between about 10 and 17 million years the universe's average temperature was suitable for liquid water (273 – 373K) and there has been speculation whether rocky planets or indeed life could have arisen briefly, since statistically a tiny part of the universe could have had different conditions from the rest, and gained warmth from the universe as a whole. :At some point around 400 to 700 million years, the earliest generations of [[stellar evolution|stars]] and [[galaxy formation and evolution|galaxies form]], and early large structures gradually emerge, drawn to the foam-like [[dark matter]] [[filament (cosmology)|filaments]] which have already begun to draw together throughout the universe. [[Population III star|The earliest generations of stars]] have not yet been observed astronomically. They may have been huge and [[metallicity|non-metallic]] with very short lifetimes compared to [[Main Sequence|most stars we see today]], so they commonly finish burning their [[hydrogen]] fuel and explode as [[supernova]]e after mere millions of years. Other theories suggest that they may have included small stars, some perhaps still burning today. In either case, these early generations of supernovae created most of the everyday [[chemical element|elements]] we see around us today, and seeded the universe with them. :[[Galaxy cluster]]s and [[supercluster]]s emerge over time. At some point, high energy photons from the earliest stars, [[dwarf galaxy|dwarf galaxies]] and perhaps [[quasar]]s led to a period of [[reionization]]. The universe gradually transitioned into the universe we see around us today, and the Dark Ages only fully came to an end at about 1 billion years. :'''4. The universe as it appears today'''. From 1 billion years, and for about 12.8 billions of years, the universe has looked much as it does today. It will continue to appear very similar for many billions of years into the future. The [[thin disk]] of [[Milky Way|our galaxy]] began to form at about 5 billion years (8.8 bn years ago),{{cite journal |last1=del Peloso |first1=E. F. |last2=da Silva |first2=L. |last3=Porto de Mello |first3=G. F. |last4=Arany-Prado |first4=L. I. |title=The age of the Galactic thin disk from Th/Eunucleocosmochronology. III. Extended sample |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |date=2005 |volume=440 |issue=3 |pages=1153–1159 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20053307 |bibcode= 2005A&A...440.1153D | arxiv=astro-ph/0506458}} and the [[formation and evolution of the Solar System|solar system]] formed at about 9.2 billion years (4.6 bn years ago), with the earliest traces of [[timeline of the evolutionary history of life|life]] on Earth emerging by about 10.3 billion years (3.5 bn years ago). :From about 9.8 billion years of cosmic time, the slowing expansion of space gradually begins to accelerate under the influence of [[dark energy]], which may be a [[scalar field]] throughout our universe. The present-day universe is understood quite well, but beyond about 100 billion years of cosmic time (about 86 billion years in the future), uncertainties in current knowledge mean that we are less sure which path our universe will take. :'''5. [[Fate of the universe|The far future]]'''. At some time the [[Stelliferous Era]] will end as stars are no longer being born, and the expansion of the universe will mean that the observable universe becomes limited to local galaxies. There are various scenarios for the far future and [[ultimate fate of the universe]]. More exact knowledge of our current universe will allow these to be better understood. ==A more detailed summary== {{further|Timeline of the formation of the Universe|Timeline of natural history|Geologic time scale|Timeline of the evolutionary history of life|Timeline of the far future}} {{further|Graphical timeline of the universe|Graphical timeline of the Big Bang|Graphical timeline from Big Bang to Heat Death|Graphical timeline of the Stelliferous Era}} Earliest stages of chronology shown below (before neutrino decoupling) are an active area of research and based on ideas which are still speculative and subject to modification as scientific knowledge improves. "Time" column is based on extrapolation of observed [[metric expansion of space]] back in the past. For the earliest stages of chronology this extrapolation may be invalid. To give one example, [[eternal inflation]] theories propose that inflation lasts forever throughout most of the universe, making the notion of "N seconds since Big Bang" ill-defined. The radiation temperature refers to the [[cosmic background radiation]] and is given by 2.725·(1+''z''), where ''z'' is the [[redshift]]. {| class="wikitable" |---- ! Epoch ! Time ! At the end of this epoch, the spherical volume of space which will become the [[observable universe]] is about 300 light-years in radius, baryonic matter density is on the order of 4 grams per m3 (about 0.3% of sea level air density) – however, most energy at this time is in electromagnetic radiation. |---- | [[Photon epoch]] | 10 s ~ 1.2·1013 s

The spherical volume of space which will become the [[observable universe]] is 42 million light-years in radius at this time.
