{{Expand list|date=August 2008}} [[Image:I-45 & Louetta Rita Evacuation.jpg|thumb|Evacuees fleeing [[Hurricane Rita]] in Texas, United States]]
This '''list of mass evacuations''' includes [[emergency evacuation]]s of a large number of people in a short period of time. An emergency evacuation is the movement of persons from a dangerous place due to the threat or occurrence of a disastrous event whether from [[Natural disaster|natural]] or [[Man-made hazards|man made]] causes or as the result of [[war]].
==Ancient times== * 480 BC – The [[Greece|Greek]] officer of state and navy commander [[Themistocles]] ordered the evacuation of [[Athens]] as a strategic countermeasure to the approaching [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] army, leading to 100,000 inhabitants being displaced in the late summer.
==1st century== * 60–61 – [[Boudica's uprising]] results in the mass evacuation of numerous [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] settlements in [[Great Britain|Britain]]. * 79 – Eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]] causes evacuation of [[Pompeii]] and surrounding areas.
==5th century== * 410 – [[Sack of Rome (410)|Sack of Rome]] by [[Visigoths]] under [[Alaric I]]. Many [[Rome, Italy|Romans]] were either taken captive and sold into slavery or later fled the devastated city.
==13th century== * 1237–1293 – [[Mongol invasion of Europe]]: Many thousands in eastern [[Europe]] are displaced or flee before each of several Mongol expeditions.
==14th century== * 1351 – Peak of the [[Black Death]], which [[Consequences of the Black Death|led to mass evacuations]] in numerous cities, ports, and villages in Asia, Europe, and [[Egypt]].
==19th century== * 1836 – The [[Battle of the Alamo|Fall of the Alamo]] results in a mass evacuation of American, [[Mexico|Mexican]], [[Tejano]], and [[Texian]] persons in what is known as the [[Runaway Scrape]].
==20th century== [[File:Evacuees from Mount Pinatubo board the USS Abraham Lincoln.jpg|thumb|U.S. military dependents board {{USS|Abraham Lincoln|CVN-72}} in the aftermath of the [[Mount Pinatubo#The 1991 eruption|1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo]].]] * April 20, 1906 – The resultant fire of the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake]] leads to evacuation by sea of 20,000 refugees.<ref>{{cite web|title=Timeline of the San Francisco Earthquake|publisher=The Virtual Museum of the City of San Francisco|url=http://www.sfmuseum.org/hist10/06timeline.html|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> * Between March 1937 and October 1938, nearly 3,000 children were evacuated from [[Spain]] to the [[Soviet Union]]. Most of the children were from the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], [[Asturias]], and [[Cantabria]]. On June 12, 1937 over 1,500 children and 75 tutors (teachers, doctors, and nurses) left the Port of [[Santurtzi]] in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] province of [[Bizkaia]] on board the ship "Habana." Similarly, nearly 4,000 children were evacuated to the United Kingdom, also on the "Habana", with the [[HMS Hood (51)|HMS Hood]] as an escort. They became, and are still known as, "los niños de la guerra" ("the war children") or the "Gernika Generation" (as regards Basques). * September 1939 – The [[evacuations of civilians in Britain during World War II]]; at the outset of [[World War II]], [[London]] and major [[Great Britain|British]] cities were evacuated, with 1.5 million displaced in the first three days of the official evacuation. The final number of evacuees reached 3.75 million. * 1939–1940 and June 1944 – The entire population of [[Finland|Finnish]] [[Karelia]], 522,000 people, was [[Evacuation of Finnish Karelia|evacuated]] during the [[Winter War]]. Some 260,000 of these returned home during the [[Continuation War]], but were evacuated again in June 1944. * May–June 1940 – [[Operation Dynamo]] was implemented, with around 439,000 British and French troops evacuated from [[Dunkirk, France]].<ref name="youtube">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=18lsxFcDrjo</ref> * 20–23 June 1940 – 24,600 people, a third of the population, are evacuated from the [[Channel Islands]] to [[England]] and [[Scotland]] ahead of the [[Occupation of the Channel Islands#Invasion|German invasion]]. * October 1940 – 1945 – [[Evacuations of children in Germany during World War II]] * October 1941 – A mass evacuation of [[Moscow]] was ordered in the face of the threat of the war estimated 1.5 million to 3 million [[Germany|German]] [[Wehrmacht]]. Two million inhabitants were displaced within two weeks. *1942 – 1945 – Evacuation and deportation of [[Ingrian Finns]] from [[Ingria]] during and after World War II. About the entire population of Ingrian Finns (estimating 70,000 people) was evacuated from [[Leningrad Oblast|Leningrad oblast]], [[Russia]] to [[Estonia]] and [[Finland]]. Those who returned after the war faced deportations to other parts of Russia. * Autumn 1944-Spring 1945 – [[Evacuation of East Prussia]] (1.8 million people) and [[Pomerania]] (various estimates range between 3 and 7 million; see [[Flight and expulsion of Germans from Poland during and after World War II]]) * June 1944 – August 1945 – [[Evacuations of civilians in Japan during World War II]] * 1945–1951 – [[Istrian exodus]] From the end of World War II through 1953, according to various data, between 250,000 and 350,000 people emigrated from these regions * May 1950 – One hundred thousand people were evacuated from [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada during the devastating [[Red River of the North|Red River]] flood of 1950.<ref>{{cite news|title=A City Submerged – Winnipeg and the Flood of 1950 – CBC Archives|publisher=[[CBC News|CBC]]|url=http://archives.cbc.ca/environment/extreme_weather/clips/3783/|accessdate=2009-02-22 }}</ref> * Between December 10 and 24, 1950, over 100,000 [[United Nations|UN]] troops who were cut off by the [[China|Chinese]] intervention forces in Northern Korea, along with an even larger number of civilian refugees, were evacuated from the [[North Korea]]n port of [[Hungnam]] during the [[Korean War]]. * July–August 1971 – 18 million people migrated from [[Bangladesh]] (then known as [[East Pakistan]]) to [[India]] to escape the military forces of [[Pakistan]] (then known as [[West Pakistan]]). This was the largest and bloodiest exodus in human history, with 4 million dead. * 26–31 December 1974 – As a result of [[Cyclone Tracy]] destroying over 85 percent of the city, more than 60,000 people from [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin, Australia]] are evacuated from the area, leaving just 10,000 people (mainly adult males) to begin the massive cleanup. * July 1974 – The complete, spontaneous evacuation in a few hours of [[Varosha (Famagusta)#1974 to present day|Varosha]] before the advancing [[Turkey|Turkish]] army; the population feared a [[massacre]]. * 1975 – [[Operation Frequent Wind]]: thousands of [[South Vietnam]]ese and the last remaining Americans evacuate [[Ho Chi Minh City|Saigon]], capital of [[South Vietnam]], before the invading [[Vietcong]] and [[Vietnam People's Army|North Vietnamese Army]] overrun the city. * July to October 1975 – After the end of the [[Portuguese colonial war]], one million [[Portugal|Portuguese]] civilians were flown from former Portuguese colonies in Africa, mainly [[Angola]] and [[Mozambique]], back to Portugal. Thousands of flights were organized by the [[Government of Portugal|Portuguese government]], using hundreds of commercial [[airplane]]s. * 1975–1979 – [[Cambodia]]: After the [[Khmer Rouge]] take over the capital of [[Phnom Penh]], all civilians are forced to [[Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia#Evacuation of the cities|evacuate the cities]] for the countryside, in order to create a new [[Communist]] society; 2–3 million displaced. * November 1979 – As a result of the [[1979 Mississauga train derailment]], the city of [[Mississauga]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] was evacuated following a [[chlorine]] leak after a freight train derailed. 218,000 were displaced. * April 1986 – The [[Chernobyl disaster]] involved an evacuation of an estimated 335,000 people following a [[nuclear meltdown]] at the [[Chernobyl]] [[nuclear power]] plant in [[Ukraine]] (then part of the [[Soviet Union]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Geographical location and extent of radioactive contamination |work=Chernobyl.info |publisher=[[Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation]] |url=http://www.chernobyl.info/index.php?navID=2 |accessdate=2007-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630071332/http://www.chernobyl.info/index.php?navID=2 |archivedate=2007-06-30 |df= }}</ref> * 13 August to 11 October 1990 – During the [[1990 airlift of Indians from Kuwait]] [[Air India#Awards and recognitions|Air India]] entered the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] for the most people evacuated by a civil airliner. Over 170,000 people were evacuated from [[Amman]] to [[Mumbai]]– a distance of 4,117 km- via 488 flights operated by Indian Airlines. The operation was carried out during the [[Persian Gulf War]] to evacuate Indian [[expatriate]]s from [[Kuwait]] and [[Iraq]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismyindia.com/air-line/airindia.html |title=Air India, History of Air India, Air India Flight Services, Air India International, Passenger Operations, Awards in Air India |publisher=Thisismyindia.com |access-date=10 June 2010}}</ref> * 24–25 May 1991 – [[Operation Solomon]], covert [[Israel]]i military operation to take 14,325 [[Beta Israel|Ethiopian Jews]] to [[Israel]]. * June 1991 – [[Operation Fiery Vigil]] was the evacuation of roughly 20,000 non-essential military and [[United States Department of Defense]] civilian personnel and their dependents from [[Clark Air Base]] and [[U.S. Naval Base Subic Bay]] back to [[Contiguous United States|CONUS]] during the [[Plinian eruption|eruption]] of [[Mount Pinatubo]] in the [[Philippines]]. * February 1995 – At least 200,000 people are evacuated in the [[Netherlands]] due to flooding.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cowell|first=Alan|title=Dutch Rivers Are Receding, But Danger to Dikes Persists|publisher=''The New York Times''|date=February 3, 1995|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE4D6133CF930A35751C0A963958260|accessdate=2008-06-02 }}</ref> * April 5, 1995 – Nearly 10.000 inhabitants of [[Pergamino, Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] were evacuated for several days because of [[flood]]ing <ref>{{cite web|title=CAPITULO IV. ESTUDIO DE CASO: PERGAMINO| url= http://www.cambioglobal.org/enso/informes/anho4/Argentina/Cap%204%20ESTUDIO%20DE%20CASO%20-%20PERGAMINO.pdf |publisher= CENTRO estudios sociales y ambientales. INFORME FINAL IAI 2004 ENSO ARGENTINA |date= 2004 |language =es}}</ref> * April 1997 – Nearly 50,000 residents of Grand Forks, North Dakota were evacuated due to flooding from the Red River of the North, which overtopped levees.<ref>Shelby, A. Red River Rising: The Anatomy of a Flood and the Survival of an American City. St. Paul, MN: Minnesota Historical Society Press/Borealis Books, 2003.</ref> *July–August 1998 – Nearly 14 million people were evacuated because of massive [[flood]]ing and [[landslide]]s in north and central [[China]], and 5.6 million houses were destroyed. An additional 300,000 people were evacuated on August 7 in anticipation of a possible breach of [[Levee|dikes]] along the [[Yangtze River]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Officials stage mass evacuations in China's deadly floods|agency=Associated Press|date=August 7, 1998|url= http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/asiapcf/9808/07/china.floods.01/index.html|accessdate=2007-10-25|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329065755/http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/asiapcf/9808/07/china.floods.01/index.html|archivedate=2008-03-29}}</ref> *1999 – The [[Kosovo War]] led to 800,000 refugees, not all of them urban residents, leaving [[Kosovo]] and being accommodated for up to three months in other parts of [[Europe]]. *September 1999 – The size of [[Hurricane Floyd]], its intensity, and its track prompted public officials to launch the largest evacuation in U.S. history, with an estimated 3 million people fleeing the storm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2000/09/14/hurricane-floyd-night-remember-day-evacuation-frustration-forget|title=Hurricane Floyd – A Night To Remember, A Day Of Evacuation Frustration To Forget|last=|first=|date=September 9, 2000|website=|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-11-15}}</ref>
==21st century== [[Image:SDFIRE2007 058brightsharp.jpg|thumb|Evacuees at evacuation site [[Mira Mesa High School]]]]
* April 2001 – 77,000 inhabitants (around 2/3 of the population) of [[Vicenza]], [[Italy]]) were evacuated for several hours so that an [[UXO|unexploded bomb]], originally dropped in World War II, could be safely disarmed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thousands Evacuated From Italian City to Detonate WWII Bomb|publisher=''People's Daily''|date=April 30, 2001|url=http://english.people.com.cn/english/200104/30/eng20010430_69000.html|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> * [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]] – Evacuations from [[skyscraper|high-rise buildings]] across the United States. This included 3200+ survivors of the [[Collapse of the World Trade Center|World Trade Center disaster]] and inhabitants of downtown [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. Numerous other evacuations of high-rises in [[Chicago]], Illinois included the [[Sears Tower]] and the Thompson Building. The evacuation of New York included the largest sea evacuation in recorded history, with over 500,000 being evacuated in 9 hours by hundreds of boats.<ref name="youtube" /> * January 2002 – 300,000 residents of the city of [[Goma]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] were evacuated in three days due to the eruption of the [[Mount Nyiragongo]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Volcano Risk Reduction: A Case Study from Goma (DRC)|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|date=December 2004|url=http://www.undp.org/cpr/disred/documents/publications/casestudy/goma.pdf|accessdate=2007-10-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026124011/http://www.undp.org/cpr/disred/documents/publications/casestudy/goma.pdf|archive-date=2007-10-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *August 2002 – The [[2002 European floods]] led to the evacuation of 50,000 residents of [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]], on 13 August, with a total of 200,000 Czechs during the second week of August.<ref>{{cite news|title=Prague battles flood waters|publisher=BBC News|date=August 14, 2002|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2192288.stm|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> Elsewhere in Europe, more than 120,000 people were evacuated in the [[Germany|German]] city of [[Dresden]], 36,000 in the German state of [[Saxony-Anhalt]], and 1,500 in [[Hungary]].<ref>{{cite web|title=EADRCC Situation Report No. 2 on the Flood/CZECH Republic|publisher=Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Coordination Centre|url=http://www.nato.int/eadrcc/floods_czech_republic/report_2002_111.pdf|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> *September 2004 – Evacuation orders were issued for over 2.8 million residents in advance of [[Hurricane Frances]], potentially the largest in Florida's history.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/WEATHER/09/05/hurricane.frances/index.html|title=Downgraded Frances blows across Florida|last=|first=|date=2004-09-05|website=CNN.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> FEMA later granted assistance to 229,500 applicants largely associated with relocation expenses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2014/08/29/ten-years-later-remembering-hurricane-frances|title=Ten Years Later: Remembering Hurricane Frances|last=|first=|date=2014-08-29|website=fema.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> *July 2005 – 20,000 people were evacuated from the city of [[Birmingham]] in the [[United Kingdom]] after a security alert due to a [[bomb scare]].<ref>{{cite news|title=British police order evac of central Birmingham district|publisher=USA Today|date=July 10, 2005|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2005-07-09-birmingham-evac_x.htm|accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> *August 2005 – [[Hurricane Katrina]] led to a mass evacuation of the city of [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], with approximately 80% of the city's population of 484,000 evacuating before the storm struck. *September 22, 2005 – At least 2.5 million evacuated coastal [[Texas]] and [[Louisiana]] due to the approach of [[Hurricane Rita]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hro.house.state.tx.us/interim/int79-2.pdf|title=Evacuation Planning in Texas: Before and After Rita|last=|first=|date=2006-02-14|website=|publisher=Texas House of Representatives. Government of Texas.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> This is the second largest evacuation in U.S. history, and the third-largest peacetime evacuation in modern times. *October 2007 – More than 1.4 million people were evacuated in the Chinese provinces of [[Zhejiang]] and [[Fujian]] in anticipation of [[Typhoon Krosa (Ineng)|Typhoon Krosa]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Yanping|first=Li|title=China Evacuates 1.4 Million People as Typhoon Krosa Hits Coast|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|date=October 24, 2007|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=ac5j8tBcaZ9w&refer=asia|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> *October 2007 – [[California wildfires of October 2007|California wildfires]] forced more than 900,000 people in [[Southern California]] to evacuate, making it the largest evacuation in [[California]]'s history<ref>{{cite news|last=Brennan|first=Peter J.|author2=Demian McLean |title=California Fires Rout Almost 1 Million People, Kill 5|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=October 24, 2007|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=a96ks3dv.3Fo&refer=us|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> and the largest evacuation for fire in United States history.<ref>http://sosdfireblog.blogspot.com/2007/11/map-shows-massive-evacuation-area.html</ref> *May 2008 – [[2008 Sichuan earthquake]]: Approximately 200,000 people are evacuated in [[Beichuan Qiang Autonomous County|Beichuan County, China]] because of flooding fears after a [[Landslide dam|landslide created dam]] became unstable.<ref>{{cite news|title=China plans mass exodus from quake zone|publisher=CNN|date=May 29, 2008|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/05/30/china.earthquake/|accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> *August 2008 – At least 1.9 million people were evacuated from coastal [[Louisiana]], including New Orleans, for [[Hurricane Gustav]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/hurricane/index.ssf/2008/08/11_million_people_evacuate_sou.html|title=1.9 million people evacuate south Louisiana|last=Anderson|first=Ed|date=2008-08-31|publisher=The Times-Picayune|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref> In western [[Cuba]], at least 300,000 people were evacuated.<ref>{{cite web|author=Will Weissert|publisher=BlueRidgeNow|date=2008-08-30|accessdate=2008-09-01|title=Gustav now Category 4, winds of 145 mph|url=http://www.blueridgenow.com/article/20080830/news/808300290}}</ref> *March 2011 – Following the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]], between 170,000 and 200,000 people are evacuated within a 50-mile radius of the [[Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]] in fear of large casualties due to [[radiation poisoning]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Radiation spike forces evacuations at Fukushima nuclear power station|publisher=guardian.co.uk home |date=March 16, 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/16/fukushima-workers-evacuate-radiation-spikes/|accessdate=2011-03-19|location=London|first=Justin|last=McCurry}}</ref> *August 2011 – A mass evacuation stretching from [[North Carolina]] to [[New York (state)|New York]] was ordered because of [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Hurricane Irene]] and its size.<ref>{{cite news|work=New York Times|date=August 27, 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/us/28hurricane-irene.html|first1=Kim|last1=Severson|first2=Dan|last2=Barry|first3=Campbell|last3=Robertson|title=Damage and Flooding Scar Atlantic Seaboard}}</ref> *June 2013 – Nearly 1,000,000 people evacuated in 12 days from [[Uttarakhand]], [[India]] due to a [[flash flood]] and landslide. This operation was completed by the [[Indian Air Force]], [[ITBP]], [[National Disaster Response Force|NDRF]], and local authorities. [[Helicopter]]s were widely used because road networks were severely damaged. *October 2013 – Nearly 975,000 people (world Bank report says close to 100,000 people) were evacuated in 36 hours from the coastal areas of [[Odisha]] (more than 850,000) and [[Andhra Pradesh]] (nearly 90,000) in the face of [[Cyclone Phailin]]. This operation was completed by the [[Indian Air Force]], [[ITBP]], [[Odisha Disaster Response Force|ODRF]], and local authorities. *December 2014 – Nearly 1,000,000 people were evacuated in the eastern [[Philippines]] before [[typhoon]] [[Typhoon Hagupit (2014)|Hagupit]].<ref>https://news.yahoo.com/typhoon-hagupit-triggers-massive-evacuation-philippines-021318742.html</ref> *April 2015 – [[Operation Maitri]] was carried out by India to evacuate stranded Indian citizens and foreigners from [[Nepal]] and humanitarian relief during the Nepal earthquake of magnitude 8.8. *April 2015 – [[Operation Raahat (India)]] was carried out by India to evacuate stranded Indian citizens from [[Yemen]]. A total of 4640 Indian citizens and 960 foreign nationals were rescued.<ref>{{cite web | title=India evacuates 4,640 nationals, 960 others from Yemen | website=www.oneindia.com | date=2015-04-10 | url=http://www.oneindia.com/india/india-evacuates-4640-nationals-960-others-from-yemen-1711703.html | access-date=2015-04-11}}</ref> *May 2016 – Approximately 88,000 people were evacuated from [[Fort McMurray]] (Canada) due to a [[2016 Fort McMurray Wildfire|wildfire]] that grew out of control quickly. This was the largest evacuation in the Province of Alberta's history. Evacuees went north to [[Oil Sands]] camps, and communities to the south.<ref>{{cite news | title=Wildfire rages in Fort McMurray as evacuees settle in Edmonton | website=www.CBC.ca | date=2016-05-04 | url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/canada/edmonton/wildfire-rages-in-fort-mcmurray-as-evacuees-settle-in-edmonton | access-date=2015-05-04}}</ref> *October 2016 – More than 2.5 million people were told to evacuate in [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and [[South Carolina]] due to the approach of [[Hurricane Matthew]], becoming the tenth most destructive in U.S. history.<ref>{{cite web | title=Hurricane Matthew batters Florida’s northeast coast; four deaths linked to storm|date=2016-08-07| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2016/10/07/hurricane-matthew-rumbles-along-floridas-coast-as-governor-warns-this-is-not-over/| access-date=2016-08-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/weather/hurricanes/experts-why-didn-people-evacuate-for-hurricane-matthew/t2LElTY1htABbNLu7kcMVM/?start=2|title=Why Didn't People Evacuate for Hurricane Matthew?|last=|first=|date=2017-06-01|website=Palm Beach Daily News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> *February 2017 – Evacuation of 188,000 civilians from the city of Oroville, California and other towns near the [[Oroville Dam]] due to impending failure of auxiliary spillway systems.<ref>http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/13/us/california-oroville-dam-spillway-failure/index.html</ref> *July to September 2017 - Evacuation of [[Cariboo Regional District]], British Columbia, Canada, resulted in 35,616 people under evacuation order or alert over 77 days due to a record-setting wildfire season, with 996,141 hectares burnt in 232 fires, and 60 homes and 167 other structures destroyed over 48,099 km<sup>2</sup>. No deaths were recorded.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cariboord.bc.ca/services/emergency-and-protective-services/emergency-operations-centre-eoc|title=Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) {{!}} Cariboo Regional District|website=Cariboo Regional District|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> *September 2017 ─ One week after [[Hurricane Harvey]] rampaged coastal Texas and Louisana, 7 million people (in [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and [[South Carolina]]) were told to evacuate due to [[Hurricane Irma]]. Low estimates of the actual number of evacuees is 700,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2017/09/09/magnitude-irma-drives-massive-evacuation-from-florida/cdbZjGJrvgIF0Todpws4VJ/story.html}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mass evacuation}} [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Lists of disasters]] [[Category:Evacuations|Evacuations]]

{{Redirect|Royal wedding|the 1951 MGM musical|Royal Wedding}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2018}} [[File:The marriage procession of Dara Shikoh - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|The [[Mughal emperors|Mughal Emperor]] [[Shah Jahan]] attends the marriage procession of his eldest son [[Dara Shikoh]]. Mughal-Era [[fireworks]] were utilized to brighten the night throughout the wedding ceremony.]]
A '''royal wedding''' is a [[marriage ceremony]] involving members of a [[royal family]]. Weddings involving senior members of the royal family are often seen as important occasions of state and attract significant national and international attention. The following is a list of notable royal weddings:
== 19th century == ===Russian Empire=== * [[Wedding of Nicholas II and Alexandra Feodorovna|26 November 1895]]: [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II]], the last [[Emperor of All Russia|Emperor of Russia]], was married to [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)|Alexandra Feodorovna]] at the [[Grand Church of the Winter Palace]].
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha|10 February 1840]]: [[Queen Victoria]], only daughter of [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn]], and successor of [[William IV of the United Kingdom|King William IV]], was married to [[Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]], Duke of Saxony, at the [[Chapel Royal]], [[St James's Palace]]. * [[Wedding of Prince George, Duke of York, and Princess Mary of Teck|6 July 1893]]: [[George V|Prince George, Duke of York]], second son of King [[Edward VII]], was married to [[Mary of Teck|Princess Victoria Mary of Teck]] at the [[Chapel Royal]], [[St James's Palace]].
== 20th century == ===Belgium=== * [[Wedding of Prince Philippe and Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz|4 December 1999]]: [[Philippe of Belgium|Prince Philippe, Duke of Brabant]], eldest child and successor to [[Albert II of Belgium|King Albert II]], was married to [[Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz]] at the [[Cathedral of St. Michael and St. Gudula]].
===Greece=== * [[Wedding of Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece, and Marie-Chantal Miller|1 July 1995]]: [[Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece]], eldest son and second child of [[Constantine II of Greece|King Constantine II]], was married to [[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece|Marie-Chantal Miller]].
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Prince Albert, Duke of York, and Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|26 April 1923]]: [[George VI|Prince Albert, Duke of York]], second son of King [[George V]] and successor to [[Edward VIII|King Edward VIII]], was married to [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother|Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Philip Mountbatten|20 November 1947]]: [[Elizabeth II|Princess Elizabeth]], eldest daughter and successor of King [[George VI]], was married to [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Anne and Mark Phillips|14 November 1973]]: [[Anne, Princess Royal|Princess Anne]], only daughter of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Mark Phillips|Captain Mark Phillips]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer|29 July 1981]]: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], eldest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Lady Diana Spencer]] at [[St Paul's Cathedral]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson|23 July 1986]]: [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]], second son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Sarah, Duchess of York|Sarah Ferguson]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones|19 June 1999]]: [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]], youngest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|Sophie Rhys-Jones]] at [[St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle]].
== 21st century == ===Bhutan=== * [[Wedding of Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck and Jetsun Pema|13 October 2011]]: [[Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck]], King of Bhutan, was married to [[Jetsun Pema]] at the [[Punakha Dzong]] in [[Punakha|Punakha, Bhutan]].
===Denmark=== * [[Wedding of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, and Mary Donaldson|14 May 2004]]: [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark|Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark]], eldest son of [[Margrethe II of Denmark]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Mary, Crown Princess of Denmark|Mary Elizabeth Donaldson]] at the [[Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen)|Church of Our Lady]], [[Copenhagen]].
===Luxembourg=== * [[Wedding of Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg, and Countess Stéphanie de Lannoy|20 October 2012]]: [[Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Hereditary Grand Duke Guillaume]], eldest son of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Stéphanie, Hereditary Grand Duchess of Luxembourg|Countess Stephanie de Lannoy]] at the [[Notre-Dame Cathedral, Luxembourg]].
===Monaco=== * [[Wedding of Albert II, Prince of Monaco, and Charlene Wittstock|1 July 2011]]: [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Albert II]], [[Monarchy of Monaco|Sovereign Prince]] of Monaco, was married to [[Charlene, Princess of Monaco|Charlene Lynette Wittstock]] at the [[Prince's Palace of Monaco]].
===Norway=== * [[Wedding of Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway, and Mette-Marit Tjessem Høiby|25 August 2001]]: [[Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway|Crown Prince Haakon of Norway]], only son of King [[Harald V of Norway]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Mette-Marit, Crown Princess of Norway|Mette-Marit Tjessem Høiby]] at the [[Oslo Cathedral]].
===Spain=== * [[Wedding of Prince Felipe and Letizia Ortiz|22 May 2004]]: [[Felipe VI of Spain|Prince Felipe of Asturias]], only son of [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]], was married to [[Queen Letizia of Spain|Letizia Ortiz]] at the [[Almudena Cathedral]] at [[Royal Palace of Madrid]], [[Madrid]].
===Sweden=== * [[Wedding of Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden, and Daniel Westling|19 June 2010]]: [[Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden|Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden]], eldest daughter and heir apparent of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Prince Daniel, Duke of Västergötland|Daniel Westling]] at the [[Stockholm Cathedral]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Madeleine and Christopher O'Neill|8 June 2013]]: [[Princess Madeleine, Duchess of Hälsingland and Gästrikland|Princess Madeleine of Sweden]], youngest child of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Christopher O'Neill]] at the [[Stockholm Palace]] Church. * [[Wedding of Prince Carl Philip and Sofia Hellqvist|13 June 2015]]: [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland|Prince Carl Philip]], Only son of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Sofia Hellqvist]] at the [[Stockholm Palace]] Church.
===Tonga=== * [[Wedding of Crown Prince Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua|12 July 2012]]: [[Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala]], Crown Prince of Tonga, was married to [[Sinaitakala Fakafanua]] at the Centennial Church in [[Nukuʻalofa]], Tonga.
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles|9 April 2005]]: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], eldest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall|Camilla Parker Bowles]] at [[Windsor Guildhall]]. * [[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton|29 April 2011]]: [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]], second grandson of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], elder son of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Lady Diana Spencer]] is second in line to the throne, was married to [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Catherine Middleton]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle|19 May 2018]]: [[Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex]], third grandson of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], younger son of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Lady Diana Spencer]] is sixth in line to the throne, was married to [[Meghan, Duchess of Sussex|Meghan Markle]] at [[St George's Chapel]], [[Windsor Castle]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank|12 October 2018]]: [[Princess Eugenie]], third granddaughter of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], younger daughter of [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]] and [[Sarah Ferguson]] is ninth in line to the throne, was married to [[Jack Brooksbank]] at [[St George's Chapel]], [[Windsor Castle]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.britishpathe.com/workspace.php?id=10826&view=list The Royal Weddings Collection - Archived newsreels of British Royal Weddings] *[http://www.itnsource.com/specials/royalengagement Royal wedding footage]
{{Wedding}}
[[Category:Royal weddings]] [[Category:Lists of events|Royal weddings]] [[Category:Royalty-related lists|Weddings]]

page.title: List of science and engineering blunders

revision.text:
This is a '''list of engineering blunders''', i.e., gross errors or mistakes resulting from grave lack of proper consideration, such as stupidity, confusion, carelessness, or culpable ignorance,<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/blunder Blunder], Dictionary.com. ''[[Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary]]'' (accessed: February 04, 2009).</ref> which resulted in notable incidents. <!-- Please list here only the incidents which are * notable * have a Wikipedia article or section * described as blunders in multiple valid sources --> *[[Fort Montgomery (Lake Champlain)]] was sometimes referred to as "Fort Blunder", because the first version of the U.S. fort was inadvertently built on the Canadian side of the border. * The [[NASA]] [[Mars Climate Orbiter]], launched in 1998, burned up in the Martian atmosphere. A mixup between metric and [[U.S. customary unit|US Standard]] measurements in the controlling software caused the spacecraft to miss its intended 140–150 km altitude above Mars during orbit insertion, instead entering the Martian atmosphere at about 57 km. * The NASA [[Genesis (spacecraft)|Genesis]] mission was an attempt to sample particles from the solar wind. It successfully collected a sample and returned to Earth. However at the last moment the landing parachute failed to open and the return capsule smashed into the ground at high speed, contaminating the samples. The parachute failure was traced to an [[Genesis (spacecraft)#Mishap_Investigation_Board_(MIB)|accelerometer installed backwards]]. * The Quebec bridge disaster. * [[Tacoma Narrows Bridge (1940)]] * [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]] caused by a faulty blowout preventer.
==See also== *[[List of disasters]] for aircraft/rail/shipwreck disasters *[[Catastrophic failure#Structural_failure|Catastrophic failure]] Structural failures *[[Space accidents and incidents]] ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20140717230517/http://blunderingboffins.altervista.org/ Drunk photons and the myth of the electromagnetic vorticity]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Engineering Blunders}} [[Category:Lists of events]] [[Category:Science-related lists]] [[Category:Error]]

revision.comment: /* Local News in the Digital Age */
revision.text:
{{Journalism sidebar}} In [[journalism]], '''local news''' refers to coverage of events, by the [[news]], in a local context that would not be an interest of another locality, or otherwise be of national or international scope. Local news, in contrast to national or international news, caters to the news of their regional and local communities; they focus on more localized issues and events.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Local Journalism and Local Media : Making the Local News|last=Franklin|first=Bob|publisher=Taylor and Francis|year=1998|isbn=|location=https://ebookcentral.proquest.com/lib/aul/detail.action?docID=240326|pages=}}</ref> Some key features of local newsrooms includes regional politics, business, and human interest stories.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Meyer|first=Kelly M.|last2=Tang|first2=Tang|date=2015-10-02|title=#SocialJournalism: Local News Media on Twitter|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14241277.2015.1107569|journal=International Journal on Media Management|volume=17|issue=4|pages=241–257|doi=10.1080/14241277.2015.1107569|issn=1424-1277}}</ref> Local news readership has been declining in recent years, according to a recent study.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Wadbring|first=Ingela|last2=Bergström|first2=Annika|date=2017-02-01|title=A Print Crisis or a Local Crisis?|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/1461670X.2015.1042988|journal=Journalism Studies|volume=18|issue=2|pages=175–190|doi=10.1080/1461670X.2015.1042988|issn=1461-670X}}</ref>
== Television == Opt-outs of local [[television news]] are frequent before, during, or after national evening news [[television program]]ming. Often times, television networks can also commission or make provisions for their local stations to produce a longer standalone local news programmes. In some cases, local television markets/viewing areas within a country may even have a dedicated 24-hour local news channel. Local news stations have also started covering less and less local politics in favor of stories that they believe will garner more clicks or attention.<ref name=":0" /> A study has also shown that there has also been less investigative journalism within local news stations in recent years.<ref name=":0" />
=== Differences === Local news largely covers the following: * local sports * local crime and justice * local weather * local business and economy * local events * local education * local politics * local traffic updates (especially during morning newscasts)
National and international news, however, tend to cover a wider range of content, including news concerning specialized institutions of wide-ranging international power or influence, such as: * (inter)national political and intergovernmental events * stock markets * (inter)national sports competitions * regional environmental events * media/entertainment events * science/technology events * air traffic/aviatory transport events * defense/security events
=== Practices in each country === In the [[United States]], local news is provided on local [[commercial broadcasting]] channels (some of which are [[television network]] [[Network affiliate|affiliate]]s). They can either be standalone newscasts that run for at least a half-hour or short segments that air attached to national morning newscasts approximately 25 and 55 minutes past the hour. As not all stations are owned and operated by a television network, the graphics, branding, and studio designs of a station's newscasts often differ from the network they are affiliated with although in recent years, affiliates have made some form of on-air reference to their corresponding networks in the branding of their newscasts. In addition, the local news departments of stations also superimpose their on-screen digital clocks, thermometers, and (occasionally) local news tickers on graphics provided by networks during morning network newscasts. Some cable channels are dedicated to local news coverage. Examples of this include [[NY1]] in New York and [[NewsChannel 8 (cable channel)|NewsChannel 8]] in the Washington DC market.
In the [[United Kingdom]], most local news is provided on a local network station with similar branding and studio design to that of the national network news. Examples of this include the nationally networked [[BBC News]] and its regional news services such as [[BBC North West Tonight]] (on [[BBC North West]]) and [[BBC Newsline]] (on [[BBC Northern Ireland]]); the nationally networked [[ITV News]] and its regional stations including [[ITV Granada]] and [[UTV (TV channel)|UTV]]. The long version of BBC and ITV's local news shows often air during the 18:00 hour on weekday evenings. STV, which simulcasts most of the ITV network's programmes in Scotland, is not owned and operated by ITV but has its own branded newscast that broadcasts Scottish-centred news at the same time as ITV's regional news services.
In France, most local news is aired on France Televisions' [[France 3]]. Additionally BFM TV also has a local news channel for the Ile-de-France region called BFM Paris.
Norway's public broadcaster, [[NRK1]], airs a local news programme called NRK Distriktsnyheter (name of viewing area) every weekday evening at 18:45 Central European Time, just before the main national newscast Dagsrevyen. A replay of all local newscasts across the country is shown on NRK2 the following morning (Tuesday to Saturday).
In Sweden, SVT's regional news is simply called SVT Nyheter (name of viewing area) which shares the same branding as the network's main newscast, Rapport. Unlike SVT's counterparts in the US and UK, during morning programmes, the local news opt-out airs in the middle of each half-hour. Since June 2007, the morning regional cut-ins no longer feature an in-studio presenters but instead show compiled short reports from various correspondents across the region. When SVT World was still airing, the simulcast of the morning programme featured a different regional opt-out during each half-hour. A 13-minute standalone local newscast airs at 18:30 Central European Time each weekday evening after Sportnytt (SVT's sport news) on SVT1. Additionally, a short local news segment is incorporated into SVT's other evening newscast Aktuellt which airs on SVT2. In that case, this local news segment shares the same branding and graphics as Aktuellt. There are no local SVT newscasts on Saturdays.
==Newspapers== A lot of newspapers specialise in covering the cities they are based in. Although paper copies of local newspapers are usually sold and circulated exclusively in the local areas they operate (with entities such as libraries or relatives wanting a copy of the paper where a family member is mentioned being mailed copies of outside of circulation areas), companies may make digital copies of their newspapers available to interested readers directly on their website or through services such as PressReader often with a paid subscription.
In the United States, although newspapers such as ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]'' have a 'national' focus on their front pages, they still have dedicated sections for news in the areas they are based in. Weather sections also highlight conditions in the local area and the sport sections feature local teams alongside national sport stories. Their local editions also feature local classified ads.
==Local News in the Digital Age== In the age of digital media, local news readership has started to fall.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":0" /> This can be attributed to the younger generation's disinterest in traditional news sources and the inability of news stations to fully integrate their business models and practices into the age of digital journalism.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> While national and international news industries began using Twitter as a way to break news and interact with their audiences, local news mediums have fallen behind, trending towards using Twitter as a secondary source for spreading information rather than a primary tool for audience engagement.<ref name=":1" />
Since Internet sites reach a larger audience, more local news agencies have started their own websites to compete in the digital age.<ref name=":0" /> Websites are a great way for local news stations to produce more interactive content, which engages the audiences and increases readership.<ref name=":1" />
Aside from the Internet, Twitter specifically has become a great way to engage the younger generation in news, gain more readership, and spread information.<ref name=":1" /> National news sources have started using Twitter to quickly notify the public of breaking news and to interact with their readers, but local news have failed to integrate Twitter and other forms of social media into their journalism practices as successfully.<ref name=":1" /> While local TV news stations have actually been a bit more effective with using social media, local newspapers have overall fallen behind.<ref name=":1" /> By engaging the audience and spreading important information, social media has been considered a solid method for strengthening the core standards of journalism.<ref name=":1" /> As a result, social media like Twitter has become a vital tool for news agencies to incorporate into their everyday practices.<ref name=":1" />
As a result of the transition to digital content, local news agencies have had to change their business models. Although they previously gained revenue from subscriptions, more agencies have started making money from online advertising, but this only accounts for a small portion of revenue.<ref name=":2" /> This loss in revenue has been linked to a decline in local journalistic integrity, because with less profit, the need to make money through clickbait articles has become a necessity.<ref name=":2" />
==See also== * [[Broadcast journalism]] * [[Citizen journalism]] * [[Open source journalism]] * [[Participatory journalism]] * [[Social media]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:News]] [[Category:Television terminology]] [[Category:Broadcast journalism]] [[Category:Hyperlocal media]]

revision.comment: Copying from [[Category:20th-century American drummers]] to [[Category:American male drummers]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Louis A. McCall Sr. | image = Louis_A._McCall.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = McCall, 1982. | alt = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Louis Anthony McCall | alias = Tony | birth_date = {{birth date|1951|12|28}} | birth_place = [[Alameda, California]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|1997|06|25|1951|12|28}}<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=nywEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA48&dq=louis+mccall&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjc1vDg-NLUAhWp8YMKHW-LCIc4ChDoAQgjMAA#v=onepage&q=louis%20mccall&f=false Vibe - November 1997]</ref> | death_place = [[Stone Mountain, Georgia]], U.S. | origin = [[Vallejo, California]], U.S. | instrument = {{hlist|Drums|vocals|percussion}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Rhythm and blues|R&B]]|[[Soul music|Soul]]|[[Funk]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Musician|songwriter|producer}} | years_active = 1969–1997 | label = {{hlist|Fretone|[[Mercury Records|Mercury]]}} | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Con Funk Shun]]|[[Cameo (band)|Cameo]]}} | website =
}} '''Louis Anthony McCall Sr.''' (December 28, 1951 – June 25, 1997) was an American singer, songwriter, drummer, and [[event planner]]. McCall is best remembered as the co-founder and drummer of the American [[Funk]]/[[R&B]] band [[Con Funk Shun]],<ref>[https://www.last.fm/music/Con+Funk+Shun LastFM - Con Funk Shun]</ref><ref>[http://www.soulwalking.co.uk/Confunkshun.html Soulwalking - Con Funk Shun]</ref> which gained fame during the 1970s and 1980s with R&B songs such as: "[[Ffun]]" (1978), "Chase Me" (1979) and "Baby I'm Hooked (Right into Your Love)" (1983). McCall's wife is music business consultant and songwriter Linda Lou McCall. In 1997, McCall was murdered in a home invasion robbery at age 45.
==Career== ===Con Funk Shun=== Louis A. McCall Sr. and singer/guitarist Michael Cooper formed Con Funk Shun as high school students in [[Vallejo, California|Vallejo]], California.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=saG0kc0lG7wC&pg=PA123&dq=louis+mccall&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj47pbn-NLUAhWM7IMKHTO-Di04FBDoAQg0MAM#v=onepage&q=louis%20mccall&f=false African Americans in Vallejo – By Sharon McGriff-Payne]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.exxtrafoxxmusic.com/con_funk_shun/|title=Exxtra Foxx Music LLC – Con Funk Shun|work=Exxtra Foxx Music LLC|date=2007-2014|access-date=April 21, 2018}}</ref> Adding members Karl A. Fuller, Paul A. Harrell, Cedric A. Martin, [[Felton C. Pilate]] and Danny A. Thomas, the band started out as a backing group for the [[Soul Children]] under the name Project Soul. They began working with [[Stax Records]] staff songwriters, and while [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] at Audio Dimensions, a sound studio in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], Tennessee, producer Ted Sturges both named the group (after an [[instrumental]] recording by [[The Nite-Liters]]) and produced their first album, ''Organized Con Funk Shun''.
In 1976, Con Funk Shun signed to [[Mercury Records]], releasing eleven albums over a span of ten years. The group's 1977 album, ''Secrets'', was certified [[gold album|gold]] in the U.S., as were ''Loveshine'' (1978), ''Candy'' (1979), and ''[[Spirit of Love]]'' (1980).<ref>Search for "Con Funk Shun" performed at [[RIAA]].com on December 10, 2007.</ref> They scored a string of [[Top 40|top ten]] [[hit single|hits]] on the [[Billboard magazine|''Billboard'']] black singles [[record chart|chart]], including "Ffun" (#1 in 1977), "Shake and Dance with Me" (#5 in 1978), "Chase Me" (#4 in 1979), "Got to Be Enough" (#8 in 1980) and "Too Tight" (#8 in 1981). Tensions from within the group built over the 1980s, and the group's final album, ''Burning Love'', was recorded without songwriter and vocalist [[Felton Pilate]], who had left Con Funk Shun following a physical altercation involving McCall.<ref name="unsung"/> The band let McCall go after he missed two concert dates in order to deal with medical problems resulting from a teenage car crash.<ref name="unsung"/> After leaving Mercury Records, the band broke up in 1986, but some members of the group reunited alongside touring musicians for concerts in the 1990s.
===Later career=== After leaving Con Funk Shun in 1986, McCall joined forces with his wife, a music business consultant, and started an artist management company in the [[Washington, DC]] area. In 1989, they discovered [[Keith Martin (musician)|Keith Martin]], an aspiring R&B artist, and signed on as his managers. When Linda Lou McCall was hired by rapper [[MC Hammer]] in 1990, the McCalls put Martin on Hammer's ''[[Please Hammer, Don't Hurt 'Em]]'' tour as a backup musician and vocalist, which launched Martin's career in the music industry. In 1992, Linda Lou formed her own company, The Entertainment Qartel, Inc. (EQartel), specializing in music business administration and entertainment marketing and promotions.<ref name=LindaLou>{{cite web|url=http://www.exxtrafoxxmusic.com/linda_lou_mccall.html|title=Exxtra Foxx Music LLC – Linda Lou McCall CEO|work=Exxtra Foxx Music LLC|date=2007-2014|access-date=April 21, 2018}}</ref> In addition to doing radio promotion for EQartel's Atlanta-based street team, the Rhyme Scene Unit, McCall also became a successful event planner, most notably producing a celebrity benefit for actor/activist [[Danny Glover]] at [[Fairmont San Francisco|The Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco]] in January 1993.
==Death and aftermath== On June 25, 1997, Louis McCall was found murdered outside a friend's home in [[Stone Mountain, Georgia]], the apparent victim of a home-invasion robbery.<ref name="unsung"/> His wife, Linda Lou, fought to keep the case active for eleven years, even asking the Governor of Georgia to assist in reopening the case in 2003. Finally, a suspect was indicted in 2007 in connection with the murder, but it took another year before the case made it to trial on July 21, 2008, with 29-year-old Marques Clair as defendant.<ref>{{cite news|last=Simpson |first=David |url=http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/stories/2008/07/21/mccall.html?cxntlid=inform_sr/ |title=Trial starts today in musician's '97 death |date=July 21, 2008 |newspaper=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525001311/http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/stories/2008/07/21/mccall.html?cxntlid=inform_sr%2F |archivedate=May 25, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Clair was originally arrested with another suspect in McCall's slaying in 1999, but prosecutors had dropped the charge due to the District Attorney's refusal to bring the case before a jury with insufficient evidence.
Just two days after the start of Clair's murder trial, the proceedings were halted by Superior Court Judge Gregory Adams. A spokeswoman for the DeKalb County Georgia district attorney's office, Jada Hudspeth, stated that the suspension of the trial was "based on an omission" of information.<ref>{{cite news |last=Simpson |first=David |url=http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/dekalb/stories/2008/07/24/slain_musician_mistrial.html |title=Mistrial declared in case of slain musician |date=July 24, 2008 |newspaper=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604101702/http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/metro/dekalb/stories/2008/07/24/slain_musician_mistrial.html |archivedate=June 4, 2011}}</ref> Hudspeth said that District Attorney, Gwen Keyes Fleming, and her staff would evaluate the evidence in the case before deciding whether to retry Clair. On August 7, 2008, after a mistrial was declared, the charges against Clair were formally [[dismissal with prejudice|dismissed with prejudice]].
==Legacy== In recognition of the fact that Louis McCall was born in Alameda, CA, his name was chosen by the Alameda City Planning Board in April 2014 for naming one of the streets in the proposed residential community, Alameda Landing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Boitano |first=Dave |url=http://thealamedan.org/news/navy-loses-battle-over-street-names |title=Navy loses battle over street names |publisher=The Alamedan |date=April 29, 2014 |access-date=February 5, 2016}}</ref>
On September 21, 2014, Louis McCall and the other six members of Con Funk Shun were honored by the National R&B Music Society with a Lifetime Achievement Award at a black tie dinner and award ceremony in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]].<ref>[http://www.rnbmusicsociety.com/#!4th-black-tie-gala-award-cerem/c10cc The National R&B Music Society] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140823055009/http://www.rnbmusicsociety.com/#!4th-black-tie-gala-award-cerem/c10cc |date=August 23, 2014 }}</ref> At the same event, McCall's wife Linda Lou was presented with the "Unsung Heroine" award for her key role in the success of Con Funk Shun and her continued role in keeping the group's legacy alive, in addition to her tireless contribution to R&B music for over four decades.<ref name=LindaLou/>
As well as being the band's leader, responsible for booking many of their most lucrative tours, Louis (along with Linda Lou) wrote several songs for Con Funk Shun, including "California 1", "Bad Lady", and "Honey Wild" (co-written with Con Funk Shun member Danny Thomas). In 2007, "Honey Wild", from the 1980 ''Spirit of Love'' album, was sampled by [[Lil Wayne]] for his Grammy Award-winning CD ''[[Tha Carter III]]''.
==Personal life== In 1968, at the age of sixteen, McCall was seriously injured in an automobile accident in Vallejo, California.<ref name="unsung">"Con Funk Shun." ''[[Unsung (TV series)|Unsung]]''. Exec. Prod. Frank Sinton, Arthur Smith, and Kent Weed. Co-Exec. Prod. Mark Rowland. Nar. Gary Anthony Williams. TV One, 9. Jul. 2012. Television.</ref> He experienced medical problems in his adult life as a result of the accident.
Louis met his wife, the former Linda Lou Bolden from Washington, DC, in 1973, when both were working at Stax Records. The couple married on January 15, 1976, in a civil ceremony in [[San Francisco]], California. They had two children, Lindsay Chérie (born in 1979) and Louis Anthony II (born in 1982). McCall and his wife separated not long before his death,<ref name="unsung"/> but the pair remained close both personally and professionally.
McCall's first grandchild, Liam Richard Long, was born on March 2, 2014, to his daughter Lindsay, a [[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]] police officer, and her husband in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]].
==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''Organized Con Funk Shun'' (1973), Fretone * ''The Memphis Sessions'' (1973), Fretone * ''Con-Funk-Shun'' (1976), [[Mercury Records|Mercury]] * ''Secrets'' (1977), Mercury * ''Loveshine'' (1978), Mercury * ''Candy'' (1979), Mercury * ''Spirit of Love'' (1980), Mercury * ''Touch'' (1980), Mercury * ''Con Funk Shun 7'' (1981), Mercury * ''[[To the Max (Con Funk Shun album)]]'' (1982), Mercury * ''Fever'' (1983), Mercury * ''Electric Lady'' (1985), Mercury * ''Burnin' Love'' (1986), Mercury
===Singles=== * "Sho Feels Good To Me" (1976) – #66 [[Black Singles Chart|Black Singles]] * "Confunkshunizeya" (1977) – #31 Black Singles * "Ffun" (1977) – #1 Black Singles, #23 Pop * "Shake And Dance With Me" (1978) – #5 Black Singles, #60 Pop Singles * "So Easy" (1978) – #28 Black Singles * "(Let Me Put) Love on Your Mind" (1979) – #24 Black Singles * "Chase Me" (1979) – #4 Black Singles * "Da Lady" (1980) – #60 Black Singles * "By Your Side" (1980) – #27 Black Singles * "Got To Be Enough" (1980) – #8 Black Singles, #20 [[Club Play Singles|Club Play]] * "Happy Face" (1980) – #87 Black Singles * "Bad Lady" (1981) – #19 Black Singles * "Lady's Wild" (1981) – #42 Black Singles * "Too Tight" (1981) – #8 Black Singles, #40 Pop Singles, #25 Club Play * "Ain't Nobody, Baby" (1982) – #31 Black Singles * "Straight From The Heart" (1982) – #79 Black Singles * "Baby I'm Hooked (Right into Your Love)" (1983) – #5 [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|Hot R&B]], #76 [[Hot 100]] * "Ms. Got-The-Body" (1983) – #15 Black Singles * "Love's Train/You Are The One" (1983) – #47 Black Singles * "Don't Let Your Love Grow Cold" (1984) – #33 Hot R&B * "Electric Lady" (1985) – #4 Hot R&B, #32 [[Hot Dance Music/Maxi-Singles Sales|Hot Dance]] * "I'm Leaving Baby" (1985) – #12 Hot R&B * "Tell Me What You're Gonna Do" (1985) – #47 Hot R&B * "Burnin' Love" (1986) – #8 Hot R&B * "She's a Star" (1986) – #80 Hot R&B * "Kush" (2008) – sample of "Honey Wild", by [[Lil Wayne]] for ''[[Tha Carter III]]''
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101006135138/http://www.theloosebook.com/louis_a_mccall.html ExxtraFoxxMusic/ Louis A. McCall] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111002160053/http://www.theloosebook.com/con_funk_shun_2/ ExxtraFoxxMusic.com/ Con Funk Shun] * [https://www.myspace.com/confunkshun707/ Con Funk Shun's MySpace page] * [https://www.myspace.com/louismccallcfs/ Louis A. McCall Sr.'s MySpace page] * [http://thealamedan.org/news/navy-loses-battle-over-street-names The Alamedan] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140823055009/http://www.rnbmusicsociety.com/#!4th-black-tie-gala-award-cerem/c10cc#!4th-black-tie-gala-award-cerem/c10cc The National R&B Music Society]
{{authority control}}

Sr.}} [[Category:African-American drummers]] [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:Musicians from California]] [[Category:People from Alameda, California]] [[Category:Event planners]] [[Category:Murdered African-American people]] [[Category:Murdered American musicians]] [[Category:People murdered in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:20th-century American drummers]] [[Category:American male drummers]]

revision.comment: Added {{[[:Template:improve categories|improve categories]]}} tag to article ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{short description|2016 hoax about marijuana cigarettes}} {{tone|date=November 2018}}
The '''Marlboro M Hoax''' was a false rumor originating from satire news website ''Abril Uno'' on April 1, 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abriluno.com/phillip-morris-introduces-marlboro-marijuana-cigarettes/|title=Phillip Morris Introduces ‘Marlboro M’ Marijuana Cigarettes|last=RapidxHTML|work=Abril Uno|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-us}}</ref> It was an [[April Fools' Day|April Fools]] joke.
== Hoax == The article claims that Philip Morris, owner of the Marlboro tobacco company, is introducing a new line of marijuana cigarettes called Marlboro M in Colorado and the state of Washington. While fake, the article does have some factual basis, as tobacco companies have shown interest in marijuana since the 1970's.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=BARRY|first=RACHEL ANN|last2=HIILAMO|first2=HEIKKI|last3=GLANTZ|first3=STANTON A.|date=2014-06|title=Waiting for the Opportune Moment: The Tobacco Industry and Marijuana Legalization|url=https://www.milbank.org/quarterly/articles/waiting-for-the-opportune-moment-the-tobacco-industry-and-marijuana-legalization/|journal=Milbank Quarterly|language=en-US|volume=92|issue=2|pages=207–242|doi=10.1111/1468-0009.12055|issn=0887-378X}}</ref> Even though the article was quite obviously satire, it's intriguing title was able to make it around the internet before it could be disproved.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/marlboro-marijuana-cigarettes/|title=FACT CHECK: Has Phillip Morris Introduced 'Marlboro M' Marijuana Cigarettes?|work=Snopes.com|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.leafly.com/news/strains-products/no-philip-morris-not-introduced-marlboro-m-cannabis-cigarette|title=False: Marlboro Marijuana Cigarettes from Phillip Morris {{!}} Leafly|date=2016-10-10|work=Leafly|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Some users, upon discovering that there were no 'Marlboro M' cigarettes at their local dispensary, claimed that they would be in stock by the end of 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/Cannettes/comments/63jxuv/what_are_marijuana_cigarettes_called_cannettes/|title=r/Cannettes - What are Marijuana Cigarettes Called? (Cannettes)|website=reddit|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>
== Basis == While the article was proven fake, its claims were able gain widespread belief because of past and current events in cannabis culture,{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} which themselves were true. For example, it is true that tobacco companies, including Phillip Morris, were interested in marijuana as a competing product and potentially an addition to their company, long before rapid legalization came about.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-features/big-tobacco-pot-weed-cannabis-industry-727407/|title=Big Tobacco Is Already Eyeing Pot|last=Benson|first=Thor|date=2018-09-25|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Legalization is also a contributing factor to the blind acceptance these claims received, as societal views on marijuana use have largely shifted in recent years. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/marycarreon/2018/05/17/new-study-highlights-the-social-impacts-of-cannabis-legalization-in-california/#1836c73e2194|title=New Study Highlights The Social Impacts Of Cannabis Legalization In California|last=Carreon|first=Mary|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en}}</ref> Some tobacco companies have actually began investing in medical marijuana research, as well as joining with marijuana seed investment firms, though they haven't gone as far is to introduce cannabis cigarettes into the market.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fool.com/investing/2018/07/22/big-tobacco-makes-its-first-investment-in-the-mari.aspx|title=Big Tobacco Makes Its First Investment in the Marijuana Industry -- The Motley Fool|last=Williams|first=Sean|date=2018-07-22|work=The Motley Fool|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}}</ref> Currently, it would be illegal for such a large company, such as Philip Morris, to introduce cannabis cigarettes, as its use is still illegal on the federal level (in the US).
== References == <references />
[[Category:Hoaxes]] [[Category:Hoaxes about drugs]]
{{improve categories|date=November 2018}}

{{for|a radio station in Hong Kong|Metro Broadcast Corporation}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = metro broadcast ltd | logo = Metro broadcast logo.jpg | type = [[Limited Company]] | foundation = Formerly Metrovideo Ltd., 1980. Bought by WPP Group plc: 1986 | location = London, England (Head office) Edinburgh, Scotland (Head office) | num_locations = Glasgow, Scotland and Aberdeen, Scotland | founder = David Pacey{{cite web |url=http://www.investegate.co.uk/article.aspx?id=20080325125433W2407 |title=West End Ventures Plc. Directorate change |date=25 March 2008 |access-date=27 August 2018 |work=FE Investegate |first=Nicholas |last=Nelson |first2=Alfred |last2=Henry Corporate |first3=Nick |last3=Michaels |publisher=[[InvestEgate]]}} (as a tape sales company) | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Event management|Event Design]]
[[Event management|Technical Event Production]]
[[Audiovisual|Audio Visual and Broadcast Services]]
[[Audiovisual|Audio Visual Hire and Installation]]{{cite web |url=http://www.incentivetravel.co.uk/news/venuesevents/22615-variety-hosts-an-evening-of-magic-at-vinopolis |title=Variety hosts an evening of magic at Vinopolis |date=6 October 2014 |access-date=27 August 2018 |work=Incentive Travel & Corporate Meetings}} | num_employees = 90+ (2016) | parent = [http://www.wpp.com wpp plc][[WPP plc|WPP Wiki]] | homepage = [http://www.metrobroadcast.com metrobroadcast.com] | footnotes = }} '''Metro Broadcast''' Ltd. is a UK-based [[Event management|corporate event]] supplier with its Head Office in London and a satellite operation in Scotland with offices in Edinburgh, Glasgow and Aberdeen. The company is a wholly owned subsidiary of [[WPP plc]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wpp.com/wpp/companies/metro/ |first=Mary |last=Metcalfe |title=Metro |access-date=27 August 2018 |work=[[WPP plc]] |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20180218060757/http://www.wpp.com:80/wpp/companies/metro/ |archive-date=18 February 2016}} Metro Broadcast is also the resident technical production supplier at several London event venues such as [[30 Euston Square]], a conference venue based at [[Royal College of General Practitioners|The Royal College of General Practitioners]], and one of Europe’s largest conference hotels, [[Hilton London Metropole]]. Metro’s production team also manages the https://www.youtube.com/yt/space/london/. Additionally, the company is a preferred event supplier at some of London’s most precious and historic buildings including [[Somerset House]], [[Natural history museum|the Natural History Museum]], [[Spencer House, London|Spencer House]], [[Worshipful Company of Barbers#Barber-Surgeons.27 Hall and Arms|Barber-Surgeons’ Hall]] and [[Middle Temple|Middle Temple Hall]]. ==History== In 1980, in a flat in [[Welling]], South East London, David Pacy,http://www.investegate.co.uk/article.aspx?id=20080325125433W2407 Managing Director and Brian Rottger, Technical Director founded Metrovideo. Its principal activity was tape sales to advertising agencies such as [[J. Walter Thompson|JWT]] (formerly J. Walter Thompson Co.), [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] and [[Young & Rubicam|Y&R]] (formerly Young & Rubicam). The company soon relocated to Landsdown Road in Stockwell and then, in April 1984, to the Old Bacon Factory in Great Suffolk Street,http://www.thetimenow.com/united_kingdom/london/audio_visual_services-92/metrovideo_ltd-1492781 London SE1. In early 1986, the business was sold to WPP plc, a British, multinational advertising and public relations company founded by [[Sir Martin Sorrell|Martin Sorrell]]. Metrovideo was the third company to be acquired by the Group. Metrovideo later acquired a number of regional video businesses for itself including Horizon Video and Still Frame Video in the South of England and Teletape Anglia in [[Cambridge]]. This expanded the sales, installation, service, AV hire and technical event productionhttp://www.incentivetravel.co.uk/news/venuesevents/22615-variety-hosts-an-evening-of-magic-at-vinopolis| areas of the company. A broadcast division of the company was located in offices in London’s [[Soho]].http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/metro-to-expand-broadcast-arm/164686.article All of these businesses traded under the Metro Group banner. In 1990, Metro launched a full-service production business called G Force which later changed its name to Clever Media. Clever Media was then merged into another WPP operating company. In 1997, the company extended its operation into [[Scotland]] by establishing an office and equipment warehouse in [[Edinburgh]]. In 2007 the Company was renamed as Metro Broadcast Ltd. In 2012 Metro Broadcast relocated its head office and main business premises to its current location in Oval, South London. In 2014 it acquired additional workshop space to house its set and staging department. Today, the London business is led by Managing Director Mary Metcalfehttp://www.citmagazine.com/article/1294808/metro-broadcast-appoints-new-creative-lead and the Scottish business is led by Managing Director Oscar Askin.http://www.eventindustrynews.co.uk/brand-marketing/metro-ecosse-appointed-national-theatre-scotland-help-deliver-24-hour-live-streamed-event-theme-independence ==Services== [[Audiovisual|Audio visual hire]]http://www.incentivetravel.co.uk/news/venuesevents/22615-variety-hosts-an-evening-of-magic-at-vinopolis|
[[Event management|Technical Event Production Services]]http://www.incentivetravel.co.uk/news/venuesevents/22615-variety-hosts-an-evening-of-magic-at-vinopolis|
[[Design–build|Stage design and build]]http://fluiddesignstudio.com/projects/metro-broadcast
[[Lighting]]http://www.incentivetravel.co.uk/news/venuesevents/22615-variety-hosts-an-evening-of-magic-at-vinopolishttp://www.lsionline.co.uk/news/story/Lighting-the-Imperial-War-Museum/L6GN9F
[[Film crew]]s
[[Video production]]http://www.focalint.org/member-news/news/787/metro-broadcast-restores-john-wayne-classics-for-dvd-box-setshttp://www.4rfv.co.uk/industrynews/180/metro_broadcast_invest_in_edifis_sd_scratchbox
[[Webcast]]http://www.eventindustrynews.co.uk/brand-marketing/metro-ecosse-appointed-national-theatre-scotland-help-deliver-24-hour-live-streamed-event-theme-independence and [[Satellite]] broadcast infrastructure and support
[[Audiovisual|Managed audio visual services]]
[[Audiovisual|Audio visual installations]] ===Links=== www.metrobroadcast.com [[WPP plc|www.wpp.com]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Companies}} *[http://www.metrobroadcast.com/ metro broadcast official website] *[http://www.metroecosse.com/ metro ecosse official website] *[http://www.wpp.com/ WPP official website] [[Category:Event management]] [[Category:Internet broadcasting]]

revision.text:
A '''Named Lecture''' is a lecture delivered usually at a predefined frequency and it is associated with a name of a person of outstanding significance to the subject the lecture is concerned with. Such lectures exist for a number of branches of Science and Engineering and they commemorate individuals who have made significant contribution to the subject.
==Science==
===Mathematics===
===Physics===
===Computer Science/Information Technology===
* [[Wheeler Lecture]] <ref>[http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/seminars/wheeler/ Wheeler Lecture]</ref>
==Engineering==
===Civil Engineering===
* BGA [[Rankine Lecture]] <ref>[http://www.icevirtuallibrary.com/info/rankine Rankine Lecture]</ref> * ASCE [[Terzaghi Lecture]] <ref>[http://www.asce.org/leadership-and-management/awards/terzaghi-lecture/ Terzaghi Lecture]</ref> * [[Coulomb Lecture]] * BGA [[Géotechnique Lecture]] * GS [[Glossop Lecture]] <ref>[http://www.geolsoc.org.uk/engineeringawards Glossop Lecture]</ref> * SECED [[Mallet-Milne Lecture]] <ref>[http://www.ice.org.uk/News-Public-Affairs/ICE-News/seced-hosts-14th-mallet-milne-lecture-at-ice Mallet-Milne Lecture]</ref> * AGS [[Poulos Lecture]] <ref>[http://australiangeomechanics.org/1931/poulos-lecture-tunnels-and-excavations-ground-movements-and-the-construction-process/ Poulos Lecture]</ref>
===Mechanical Engineering===
* ASME [[Timoshenko Lecture]] <ref>[http://imechanica.org/node/177 Timoshenko Lecture]</ref>
===Electrical Engineering===
==References==
{{Reflist}}
[[Category:Organized events]] [[Category:Academic conferences]]
